{"uri": "2024-06-393402315", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:42:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:42:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:00:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.aol.com/us-house-freedom-caucus-chair-110018431.html", "title": "US House Freedom caucus chair faces tough Virginia primary after Trump endorses rival", "body": "US House Freedom caucus chair faces tough Virginia primary after Trump endorses rival\n\nJoan E Greve in Washington\n\nJune 18, 2024 at 1:00 PM\n\nRepresentative Bob Good has accomplished the rare feat of unifying Donald Trump and allies of the former House speaker Kevin McCarthy, who are collectively trying to unseat the chair of the hard-right Freedom caucus.\n\nGood heads into his Tuesday primary in Virginia's fifth congressional district facing a challenge from the Republican state senator John McGuire, who has received a crucial endorsement from Trump. Good had already drawn the ire of fellow House Republicans for voting to oust McCarthy as speaker last year, but the incumbent's job appears to be in much more serious jeopardy after Trump's endorsement.\n\nTrump, seemingly still outraged over Good supporting Florida governor Ron DeSantis in the Republican presidential primary, has praised McGuire as \"a true American Hero\". Good's eventual endorsement of Trump, which came after DeSantis withdrew from the presidential primary in January, failed to appease the former president.\n\n\"Bob Good is BAD FOR VIRGINIA, AND BAD FOR THE USA,\" Trump wrote on Truth Social last month. \"He turned his back on our incredible movement, and was constantly attacking and fighting me until recently, when he gave a warm and 'loving' Endorsement - But really, it was too late.\"\n\nRelated: Virginia home of mother of January 6 police officer swatted\n\nTrump went so far as to send Good a cease and desist letter, demanding that his campaign stop using the former president's name and likeness to promote his re-election effort.\n\nBurdened with Trump's claims of disloyalty, Good is simultaneously fending off attacks from more establishment-minded Republicans, who say the Freedom caucus chair has undermined the party's agenda. In addition to voting for McCarthy's removal, Good has pushed for aggressive funding cuts, even calling on Republicans to force a government shutdown over the issue, and rejected all four components of a foreign aid package that provided money to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan.\n\nMcCarthy and his allies have rallied around McGuire despite the fact that his policy views largely align with Good's. For example, Good was one of the 139 House Republicans who voted against certifying Joe Biden's victory in the 2020 election, while McGuire actually attended Trump's rally that preceded the January 6 attack on the Capitol. McGuire has said that he only attended the rally and did not enter the Capitol itself.\n\nIn the final days leading up to the primary, several House Republicans have traveled to Good's district to campaign for McGuire. McCarthy himself has encouraged his supporters to donate to McGuire's campaign, and outside groups have spent heavily against Good. The American Patriots Pac, which has thrown its support behind McGuire, has already spent more than $4.3m in the race.\n\nBut Good is not without allies in the race, as fellow members of the House Freedom caucus have rallied around him. Congressman Matt Gaetz, who spearheaded the effort to remove McCarthy as speaker, has urged voters to back Good, and hard-right groups have offered their financial support as well. The Conservative Outsider Pac has spent more than $2.5m in its effort to re-elect Good.\n\nIn total, outside groups have dumped more than $10m into the fifth district, according to OpenSecrets. The hefty investment has not produced a clear frontrunner in the race, as recent polls present conflicting evidence about whether Good or McGuire has the advantage heading into Tuesday.\n\nIf Good can make it out of the primary, he is poised to win a third term, as the Cook Political Report rates the fifth district as solid Republican. But Good's disastrous political miscalculation of endorsing DeSantis may very well cost him his seat.\n\nAlthough the fifth district is not considered a toss-up in the general election, other Virginia races will carry significant implications for the national fight over control of Congress.\n\nTrump has endorsed Navy veteran Hung Cao in the Republican Senate primary, but the winner of that race will face an uphill climb to unseat the Democratic Senator Tim Kaine in the general election. Two of Virginia's House seats are also considered competitive, with the Cook Political Report rating the seventh district as lean Democrat and the second district as lean Republican.\n\nIn the seventh district, Democratic incumbent Abigail Spanberger has launched a gubernatorial campaign instead of seeking re-election, and her absence has kicked off a hotly contested primary. Eugene Vindman, who attracted national attention for his role in Trump's first impeachment trial, has significantly out raised his Democratic rivals and is favored in the race. The winner of the primary will go on to face one of six Republican candidates seeking their party's nomination.\n\nIn the second district, Republican incumbent Jen Kiggans is slightly favored to win reelection, but a Democratic over performance could put her seat in play. After Democrats' impressive showing in Virginia's legislative races last year, party leaders hope the state can help them rebuild a House majority in November.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", {"uri": "8185838611", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:11:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:11:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:08:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2751677/", "title": "Cliffhanger Congressional Contest Between Bob Good and John McGuire Tests Power of Trump Endorsement - ExBulletin", "body": "FALLS CHURCH, Va. (AP) One of America's most conservative members of Congress found himself locked in a tight re-nomination battle against an opponent backed by former President Donald Trump in Virginia's primary election Tuesday .\n\nRep. Bob Good, who chairs the far-right House Freedom Caucus, is seeking a third term to represent Virginia's 5th Congressional District, but state Sen. John McGuire has mounted a strong challenge that highlights the friction within the party.\n\nBallots remained to be counted and the tight margin made the race too early to call. Virginia observes the Juneteenth holiday and therefore is not expected to count votes on Wednesday. McGuire led Good by 327 votes, or 0.52 percentage points, out of 62,495 ballots counted as of midnight Wednesday.\n\nMeanwhile, Democrats in northern and central Virginia have been choosing candidates to replace popular incumbents who are not seeking re-election. In House District 7, Eugene Vindman won a crowded Democratic primary to try to hold on to the seat vacated by U.S. Rep. Abigail Spanberger, who is running for governor in 2025, while Republicans chose Derrick Anderson.\n\nAnd in District 10, voters chose Suhas Subramanyam among 12 Democrats to try to hold on to the seat held by U.S. Rep. Jennifer Wexton, who is not seeking re-election to her northern Virginia seat after receiving a diagnosis of a rare and incurable neurological disease. . Republican voters nominated Mike Clancy for this seat.\n\nStatewide, voters chose Hung Cao as the Republican candidate for U.S. Senate to take on Democrat Tim Kaine.\n\nWhat you need to know about the 2024 elections\n\nHere is an overview of the main battles in the election:\n\nHouse District 5\n\nConventional politics might suggest that a member of Congress with Good's conservative credentials would be safe in a primary. But he drew Trump's ire when he endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis for president. He returned to Trump after DeSantis dropped out, but Trump supports McGuire and describes Good as a traitor.\n\nTrump continued to criticize Good as he campaigned for McGuire during a telephone rally Monday evening.\n\nUnlike Bob Good, John McGuire won't let you down, Trump said, adding that McGuire is strong on the border and will always defend your embattled Second Amendment.\n\nGood says he considers Trump the best president of his lifetime and only supported DeSantis because Trump is constitutionally limited to just one more term.\n\nMcGuire, for his part, claimed victory Tuesday night and thanked Trump for believing in me. No winner has been announced by the Associated Press.\n\nThere are still a few votes to be counted, but it is clear that all paths lead to victory, McGuire said in a written statement.\n\nGood, meanwhile, released a statement on social media saying his campaign had implemented the best early voting operation the 5th District has ever seen.\n\nWe are still waiting for the results of the absentee and provisional votes, he said. We are doing what we can to ensure that we have teams of observers and legal advisors to ensure that all votes are counted correctly in the coming days.\n\nGood also alienated Republican insiders by voting to oust House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, plunging the party into some measure of chaos.\n\nSeeking to capitalize is McGuire, a state lawmaker and former Navy SEAL, who echoed Trump's attacks on Good, calling him a never-Trumper.\n\nGood criticized McGuire as a serial activist who announced his candidacy for Congress just a week after winning election to a four-year term in the state Senate.\n\nIf Good loses, he would be the first House incumbent to face a primary challenge this year, except for a race in which two incumbents faced off due to redistricting.\n\nThe winner will face Democrat Gloria Tinsley Witt, who defeated Gary Terry and Paul Riley.\n\nThe 5th Congressional District stretches from Charlottesville north, past the far western suburbs of Richmond, through Lynchburg and on to Danville and the North Carolina border.\n\nHouse District 7\n\nVindman, a political newcomer who was nevertheless known to voters for his role in Trump's first impeachment, won the Democratic nomination in the 7th Congressional District for what will be a closely watched Congressional seat in November.\n\nVindman, who crushed her opponents at the fundraiser, won against a field of seven people, including four women of color, all of whom were current or former officials in Prince William County, a suburban area in outside the national capital which constitutes the largest part of the district. .\n\nThe former Army officer gained some fame when he and his twin brother, Alex, raised concerns about Trump's 2019 call to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, in which Trump demanded an investigation into Biden and his son, Hunter.\n\nVindman emphasized his opposition to Trump in his campaign and said in a victory declaration released Tuesday evening that our grassroots movement is moving toward MAGA's extreme agenda. Virginia voters are driven by values above all and want to elect leaders with integrity who preserve fundamental rights and freedoms, not extremists.\n\nIt was criticized by some local officials who said it was not connected to the region's political dynamics.\n\nIn a battle between a former Army Green Beret and a former Navy SEAL, Republican voters chose Army man Anderson over Navy veteran Cameron Hamilton.\n\nAnderson and Hamilton were the top two fundraisers out of a field of six. Anderson gained the support of House GOP leaders in Washington, while Hamilton had the support of members of the House Freedom Caucus.\n\nThe district, which stretches from Prince William County south to Fredericksburg and west past Culpeper, leans slightly Democratic.\n\nHouse District 10\n\nSubramanyam defeated fellow Democratic candidates former Virginia House Speaker Eileen Filler-Corn, state Senators Dan Helmer and Jennifer Boysko, and former Virginia Secretary of Education Atif Qarni. Wexton endorsed Subramanyam.\n\nRepublican voters chose Clancy over four candidates.\n\nHouse District 2\n\nIn Virginia's coastal 2nd Congressional District, Missy Cotter Smasal, a Navy veteran who runs a nonprofit that honors fallen servicewomen, defeated Jeremiah Jake Denton IV, a constitutional and civil rights attorney , during the Democratic primary.\n\nShell will face Republican U.S. Rep. Jen Kiggans in November.\n\nIn a statement Tuesday evening, Smasal took aim at Kiggans and the MAGA extremism she supports in Congress.\n\nI will protect the right and access to abortion for all and fight for resources for veterans and military families, Smasal said. I will always defend democracy and reject partisan extremism.\n\nUS Senate\n\nIn the Republican primary for U.S. Senate, Navy veteran Cao got the better of his four opponents in an attempt to unseat Kaine, a Democrat who is seeking his third term as a junior U.S. senator.\n\nAmong the Republican candidates in the primary, Cao had the most money and previous campaign experience for a senior officer position. He also had the support of Trump.\n\nIn a victory message on Facebook, Cao immediately criticized President Joe Biden's decision Tuesday to allow some spouses of U.S. citizens without legal status to potentially apply for citizenship.\n\nTomorrow we will begin our campaign to save the country that saved my life, Cao said. I spent twenty-five years in the Navy, while Tim Kaine spent thirty years in elected office.\n\nCao defeated Scott Parkinson, a former DeSantis congressman, as well as Jonathan Emord, an author and lawyer who often cites his legal battles against the Food and Drug Administration. The other Republican candidates were Eddie Garcia, a U.S. Army veteran who owns a mobile app serving veterans, and Chuck Smith, a former commander of the Navy Judge Advocate General Corps and an attorney.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184747206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:16:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:16:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:11:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/freedom-caucus-chairman-locked-tight-055633008.html", "title": "Freedom Caucus chairman locked in tight primary versus Trump-backed challenger", "body": "GOP Rep. Bob Good, the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, was locked in a close primary fight Tuesday night against a challenger backed by powerful Republicans including former President Donald Trump and former Speaker Kevin McCarthy.\n\nJust a few hundred votes separated state Sen. John McGuire in the lead and Good close behind him in Virginia's deep-red 5th District as of late Tuesday night. If the margin stays within 1 percentage point, the losing candidate can request a recount within 10 days after the election results are certified, according to Virginia state law.\n\nGood is at risk of becoming the first sitting lawmaker to lose to a primary challenger this year.\n\nLate Tuesday night, Good urged his supporters to \"keep the faith\" in a lengthy post on X.\n\n\"The entire DC Swamp was aligned against us with over $10 million in attack ads, but with your help we were able to make this race too close to call,\" he wrote, touting his campaign's early vote operation and noting that there are outstanding mail-in and provisional ballots.\n\n\"We are doing what we can to ensure we have teams of observers and legal counsel to ensure all the votes are properly counted in the coming days,\" Good added.\n\nGood drew McCarthy's ire as is one of eight Republicans who voted to oust him last year. McGuire vastly outspent Good on the airwaves and outside groups aligned with McCarthy also outspent the Virginia congressman's allies, according to the ad tracking firm AdImpact.\n\n\"This is the Kevin McCarthy revenge tour,\" Good told NBC News on Friday at an event in Goochland, Va.\n\n\"He has devoted his life apparently to trying to exact some revenge on those he holds responsible for him not being Speaker, except himself,\" Good later added. \"But the people of the 5th District are not going to be bought.\"\n\nMcGuire also had the most coveted endorsement in GOP primaries: Trump.\n\nMcGuire thanked Trump Tuesday night as he declared victory, despite the race remaining very close.\n\n\"This is a time where we need to come together because we still have a lot of work to do. I'm your Republican nominee but I'm not going to take it lightly,\" Good said at his election night party, according to a livestream of his election night speech from ABC13.\n\nMcGuire said Trump is \"a huge part of our win and I will not forget that.\"\n\nThe challenger couched things a little more in a statement from his campaign: \"There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory.\"\n\nThe former president endorsed McGuire three weeks before Tuesday's primary, making a veiled reference to Good backing Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the presidential primary. Good's subsequent endorsement of Trump wasn't enough to put him in the former president's good graces.\n\nAfter backing McGuire, Trump appeared in a TV ad and held a tele-rally for McGuire on Monday night, telling supporters, \"John is running against Bob Good, who is not good. Despite his name, he's very bad for Virginia.\"\n\nMcGuire, a former Navy SEAL whose campaign slogan was, \"We can do better than Good,\" told NBC News at a community concert in Powhatan on Friday that Trump's endorsement was helpful in the race.\n\n\"I've had many people say 'I don't know anything about you, never met you before, but if Trump's endorsing you, I've got you,'\" McGuire said. \"I believe with all that Trump has been through he has earned the right to call the shots and pick his team.\"\n\nBut Good is no stranger to running against a Trump-backed candidate. In 2020, Good defeated then-Rep. Denver Riggleman at a party convention, conducted via a drive-through amid the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nOklahoma GOP Rep. Tom Cole was also on defense Tuesday but saw off his chief primary opponent, businessman Paul Bondar, who spent millions of dollars of his own money on the race. Cole, who chairs the powerful House Appropriations Committee, got a boost from Trump in the race and recently told NBC News that Trump's endorsement was \"enormously helpful\" as he faced the most competitive and expensive primary since he was first elected in 2002.\n\nBondar loaned his campaign $5.1 million of his own money, launching ads that accused Cole of losing touch with the 4th District and spending too much time in the nation's capital. Bondar also said Cole was not sufficiently conservative, pointing to Cole's support for government spending and aid to Ukraine.\n\nCole and his allies blanketed the airwaves with ads accusing Bondar of actually being a Texan. Bondar does own property in Oklahoma, outside of the 4th District, but he did vote in Texas' primaries in March.\n\nElsewhere in Virginia on Tuesday, Republican voters chose Navy veteran Hung Cao to take on Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine in November, NBC News projects. Cao, who had Trump's endorsement in the race, led the Republican field in fundraising and defeated two other GOP contenders.\n\nCao ran unsuccessfully for Congress in 2022, losing to Democratic Rep. Jennifer Wexton by nearly 7 points. He is in for a tough race against Kaine, who is running for a third term in a state that has sent Democrats to the Senate in recent years. Biden won the state by 10 points in 2020 and Kaine won a second term in 2018 by 17 points.\n\nIn the House, Democrats are also picking a candidate to take on Republican Rep. Jen Kiggans in the 2nd District, and both parties are picking their nominees in the open 7th and 10th Districts.\n\nRetired Army Col. Yevgeny \"Eugene\" Vindman is projected to win the Democratic nomination in the 7th District, giving Democrats a high-profile candidate with military experience and strong fundraising chops, He hopes to hold the seat for Democrats in the fall despite the decision by Democratic Rep. Abigail Spanberger, another strong fundraiser with a national security background, to run for governor.\n\nVindman gained national notoriety during Trump's first impeachment trial, when he and his brother raised concerns, from their perch on the National Security Council, about Trump's phone conversation with the Ukrainian president in 2019. Despite being a first-time candidate, he was far-and-away the best fundraiser in the race, and got a boost from outside groups on the airwaves as he ran against more experienced local politicians.\n\nHe'll face off against Derrick Anderson, a former Green Beret, who bested former Navy SEAL Cameron Hamilton in a clash between the establishment and insurgent wings of the party. Anderson was backed by a super PAC tied to McCarthy and Republican megadonors, as well as House Speaker Mike Johnson.\n\nIn the 10th District, state Sen. Suhas Subramanyam is projected to win the crowded and expensive Democratic primary in Virginia's 10th District, where Democratic Rep. Jennifer Wexton is not seeking re-election after being diagnosed with a rare and serious condition called progressive supranuclear palsy.\n\nSubramanyam won Wexton's endorsement, which helped him separate himself from a crowded field of well-funded Democrats that included state Del. Dan Helmer, former state Assembly Speaker Eileen Filler-Corn and former Defense Department official Krystle Kaul. He'll be in the driver's seat to hold the district for Democrats in the fall, as Democrats have performed well recently in this suburban-Washington D.C. district, and will face off against Republican businessman and lawyer Mike Clancy.\n\nKiggans will face Democrat Missy Cotter Smasal, a military veteran who had been backed by Virginia's every Democratic House member from Virginia. This is a swing district that's likely to be competitive in the fall, but Kiggans has a significant fundraising edge and defeated a Democratic incumbent there to win the seat in 2022.\n\nGeorgia also held its primary runoffs in races where no candidate won a majority of the primary vote back in March.\n\nIn the Democratic-leaning 2nd District, activist Chuck Hand, who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor offense in connection with the attack on Jan. 6, 2021, lost a runoff for the Republican nomination.\n\nAnd Trump's former White House political director, Brian Jack, is projected to win his GOP primary runoff against state Sen. Mike Dugan. The Republican will be the heavy favorite to win in November to replace retiring GOP Rep. {"uri": "8185858239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:28:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:28:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:27:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.wtaj.com/hill-politics/bob-good-fights-for-political-life-as-gop-primary-heads-for-likely-recount/", "title": "Bob Good fights for political life as GOP primary heads for likely recount", "body": "Rep. Bob Good (R) is still fighting for his political life the day after polls closed in Virginia.\n\nThe bitter race between Good, the chair of the House Freedom Caucus, and his primary challenger, John McGuire -- a state senator who won the coveted endorsement of former President Trump -- remained too close to call as of Wednesday afternoon, with McGuire holding a razor-thin edge over Good.\n\nMcGuire is leading Good by just 307 votes -- or 0.4 percent -- with 95 percent of the vote in, according to results from The Hill/Decision Desk HQ. More than 62,000 voters cast ballots in the race to represent Virginia's 5th Congressional District.\n\nThe contest is almost certainly headed to a recount: Virginia law allows candidates to request a recount if the margin is less than one percent.\n\nGood expressed confidence Wednesday morning that he has a path to victory, but warned that the final stretch of counting could take weeks.\n\n\"Provisional ballots and mail-in ballots are also still to be counted. We are asking for full transparency from the officials involved and patience from the people of the 5th District over the coming weeks as the certification of results is completed,\" Good wrote on X. \"We believe we can still prevail.\"\n\nMcGuire, meanwhile, encouraged by his late lead Tuesday night, went ahead and declared victory in a room full of supporters, taking a page from Trump's 2020 election playbook.\n\n\"Ladies and gentleman, the votes are in and the people have spoken: It is an honor to be your Republican nominee for the 5th congressional district,\" McGuire declared, prompting cheers.\n\nHe echoed that sentiment overnight Wednesday, writing on X: \"There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory.\"\n\nCounting could be at least delayed until Thursday. Virginia observes Juneteenth, a federal holiday, so ballots are not expected to be tallied on Wednesday, according to The Associated Press.\n\nGood, however, is optimistic that he will take the edge as more votes are counted.\n\nA handful of counties in the Old Dominion had a fair portion of outstanding ballots as of Wednesday morning, with both Good and McGuire leading in some of the areas.\n\nA source close to the Good campaign told The Hill that they are closely watching returns in Albemarle and Lynchburg Counties, both of which the incumbent has a leg up in.\n\nIn Albemarle, Good has a 523 vote -- or 9.4 point -- edge over McGuire with much of the county reporting. Over in Lynchburg, Good is hanging on to an 842 vote -- or 16.4 percent -- lead over McGuire.\n\n\"This race remains too close to call,\" Good wrote on X Wednesday. \"We are in a period where the law provides a process for evaluating the accuracy of all the vote totals from election day to ensure everyone can have full confidence in the certified results.\"\n\nThe battle in Virginia's 5th Congressional District -- Tuesday's marquee race -- has drawn national headlines for months, both for its intense interest inside the beltway and heavy spending.\n\nTrump and former Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) both endorsed McGuire after Good crossed them -- Good initially backed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the GOP presidential primary, and he voted to oust McCarthy from the top job -- earning the incumbent the ire of two GOP heavyweights, their supporters -- and their warchests.\n\nTrump declared in a Truth Social post on the eve of Election Day that \"Bob Good is BAD FOR VIRGINIA, AND BAD FOR THE USA,\" and participated in a tele-rally for McGuire, where he warned that if Good is elected the incumbent \"will stab Virginia in the back, sort of like he did with me.\"\n\nMcCarthy's Majority Committee PAC, meanwhile, funneled $10,000 to McGuire's campaign, looking to knock off the first of eight Republicans who voted to remove him from the Speakership. He faced his first defeat last week after Rep. Nancy Mace (R-S.C.), who voted to remove McCarthy, reigned supreme in her primary.\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.), another GOP firebrand, joined Trump and McCarthy in backing McGuire, while other Freedom Caucus members on Capitol Hill backed their chairman, including Reps. Chip Roy (R-Texas), Byron Donalds (R-Fla.) and Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.).\n\nGood nodded to that opposition against him in an Election night post on X, writing: \"No matter the outcome, you've shown the DC Swamp that you won't back down from standing for what's right.\"\n\n\"Keep the faith and don't stop fighting now,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": "wtaj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTAJ - {"uri": "8183466868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:12:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:12:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:10:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jun/18/house-freedom-caucus-chair-virginia-primary-trump", "title": "US House Freedom caucus chair faces tough Virginia primary after Trump endorses rival", "body": "Ex-president and McCarthy allies have joined to unseat Bob Good from the state's fifth congressional district\n\nRepresentative Bob Good has accomplished the rare feat of unifying Donald Trump and allies of the former House speaker Kevin McCarthy, who are collectively trying to unseat the chair of the hard-right Freedom caucus.\n\nGood heads into his Tuesday primary in Virginia's fifth congressional district facing a challenge from the Republican state senator John McGuire, who has received a crucial endorsement from Trump. Good had already drawn the ire of fellow House Republicans for voting to oust McCarthy as speaker last year, but the incumbent's job appears to be in much more serious jeopardy after Trump's endorsement.\n\nTrump, seemingly still outraged over Good supporting Florida governor Ron DeSantis in the Republican presidential primary, has praised McGuire as \"a true American Hero\". Good's eventual endorsement of Trump, which came after DeSantis withdrew from the presidential primary in January, failed to appease the former president.\n\n\"Bob Good is BAD FOR VIRGINIA, AND BAD FOR THE USA,\" Trump wrote on Truth Social last month. \"He turned his back on our incredible movement, and was constantly attacking and fighting me until recently, when he gave a warm and 'loving' Endorsement - But really, it was too late.\"\n\nTrump went so far as to send Good a cease and desist letter, demanding that his campaign stop using the former president's name and likeness to promote his re-election effort.\n\nBurdened with Trump's claims of disloyalty, Good is simultaneously fending off attacks from more establishment-minded Republicans, who say the Freedom caucus chair has undermined the party's agenda. In addition to voting for McCarthy's removal, Good has pushed for aggressive funding cuts, even calling on Republicans to force a government shutdown over the issue, and rejected all four components of a foreign aid package that provided money to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan.\n\nMcCarthy and his allies have rallied around McGuire despite the fact that his policy views largely align with Good's. For example, Good was one of the 139 House Republicans who voted against certifying Joe Biden's victory in the 2020 election, while McGuire actually attended Trump's rally that preceded the January 6 attack on the Capitol. McGuire has said that he only attended the rally and did not enter the Capitol itself.\n\nIn the final days leading up to the primary, several House Republicans have traveled to Good's district to campaign for McGuire. McCarthy himself has encouraged his supporters to donate to McGuire's campaign, and outside groups have spent heavily against Good. The American Patriots Pac, which has thrown its support behind McGuire, has already spent more than $4.3m in the race.\n\nBut Good is not without allies in the race, as fellow members of the House Freedom caucus have rallied around him. Congressman Matt Gaetz, who spearheaded the effort to remove McCarthy as speaker, has urged voters to back Good, and hard-right groups have offered their financial support as well. The Conservative Outsider Pac has spent more than $2.5m in its effort to re-elect Good.\n\nIn total, outside groups have dumped more than $10m into the fifth district, according to OpenSecrets. The hefty investment has not produced a clear frontrunner in the race, as recent polls present conflicting evidence about whether Good or McGuire has the advantage heading into Tuesday.\n\nIf Good can make it out of the primary, he is poised to win a third term, as the Cook Political Report rates the fifth district as solid Republican. But Good's disastrous political miscalculation of endorsing DeSantis may very well cost him his seat.\n\nAlthough the fifth district is not considered a toss-up in the general election, other Virginia races will carry significant implications for the national fight over control of Congress.\n\nTrump has endorsed Navy veteran Hung Cao in the Republican Senate primary, but the winner of that race will face an uphill climb to unseat the Democratic Senator Tim Kaine in the general election. Two of Virginia's House seats are also considered competitive, with the Cook Political Report rating the seventh district as lean Democrat and the second district as lean Republican.\n\nIn the seventh district, Democratic incumbent Abigail Spanberger has launched a gubernatorial campaign instead of seeking re-election, and her absence has kicked off a hotly contested primary. Eugene Vindman, who attracted national attention for his role in Trump's first impeachment trial, has significantly out raised his Democratic rivals and is favored in the race. The winner of the primary will go on to face one of six Republican candidates seeking their party's nomination.\n\nIn the second district, Republican incumbent Jen Kiggans is slightly favored to win reelection, but a Democratic over performance could put her seat in play. After Democrats' impressive showing in Virginia's legislative races last year, party leaders hope the state can help them rebuild a House majority in November.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", {"uri": "8185815627", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:47:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:47:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:47:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.wric.com/news/politics/local-election-hq/virginias-5th-district-gop-primary-between-bob-good-and-john-mcguire-could-head-to-recount/", "title": "Virginia's 5th District GOP primary between Bob Good and John McGuire could head to recount", "body": "RICHMOND, Va. (WRIC) - The margin between Republican incumbent Bob Good and his Trump-backed challenger John McGuire in Virginia's 5 Congressional District primary is in recount territory and votes still need to be counted.\n\nState Sen. McGuire (R-Goochland) leads Rep. Good (R-Va.), who chairs the House Freedom Caucus, by 309 votes (31,377 to 31,068), per the state's unofficial count as of noon Wednesday, with provisional ballots and mail-in ballots sent by Tuesday still to be included.\n\nThis 0.5% difference is within the 1% margin needed for a potential recount in Virginia, which, if it holds after the results are certified by the State Board of Elections, would ultimately be paid for by the state instead of Good.\n\nStill, McGuire declared victory Tuesday night.\n\n\"There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory,\" McGuire said in a statement minutes before midnight.\n\nNearly an hour before McGuire's declaration, Good told supporters on social media that his campaign was \"still waiting on the final election results.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, Good said he believes he can still win and is asking for \"full transparency from the officials involved and patience from the people of the 5th District over the coming weeks as the certification of results is completed.\"\n\n\"This race remains too close to call,\" Good wrote on X on Wednesday. \"We are in a period where the law provides a process for evaluating the accuracy of all the vote totals from election day to ensure everyone can have full confidence in the certified results.\"\n\nLocal electoral boards still need to go over the unofficial primary returns and any potential errors, including reviewing provisional ballots that could or could not be accepted and ballots mailed in by Tuesday to local election offices.\n\nIn his bid to deny Good a third term, McGuire picked up an endorsement from former President Donald Trump that political experts said was key in his push to unseat an incumbent in a red-leaning district.\n\nThe 5 District stretches from the Charlottesville area to the North Carolina border, including the cities of Lynchburg and Danville and Louisa, Powhatan, and Goochland counties. It also includes part of Hanover County.\n\nThe Good-McGuire head-to-head was one of the most closely watched primaries by political experts. It pitted two far-right conservatives against each other who appear aligned on major policy points in a potential litmus test on Trump's influence in Virginia.\n\nIt was also one of the most expensive primaries, with the Virginia Public Access Project reporting that nearly $10.9 million was spent in the race.\n\nTrump endorsed McGuire over Good after the congressman backed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the GOP presidential primary over Trump. Good ultimately endorsed Trump after DeSantis dropped out, but the former president said the switch was \"too late\" and the \"damage had been done.\"\n\nAnd the day before Tuesday's primary, Trump took part in a tele-town hall for McGuire in which he said the state senator had his \"complete and total endorsement\" and called Good \"not good.\"\n\nDespite Trump campaigning against him, Good joined McGuire in making Trump a focal point in the primary. They aligned themselves with the former president and invoked his name during their campaigns.\n\nMcGuire made Trump's endorsement a central focus of his campaign, touting the former president's support in ads, signs and even his transportation. Good also focused on Trump, including using campaign signs with Trump's name that he was asked to take down.\n\nThe winner of the GOP primary will go up against Democrat Gloria Witt in November. The Associated Press called the 5th District's Democratic primary for Witt, the founder and CEO of a business executive coaching company, on Tuesday.\n\n8News relies on The Associated Press for race calls. All election results are unofficial until certified by the State Board of Elections.\n\nThere are no automatic recounts in Virginia. The losing candidate can petition for one and if the margin is within 0.5%, the state pays the cost. If it is between that and 1%, the losing candidate covers the cost.", "source": {"uri": "wric.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "8News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dean_mirshahi@wric.com", "name": "Dean {"uri": "2024-06-395975639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:34:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:34:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:13:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/newsfront/bob-good-john-mcguire-virginia/2024/06/20/id/1169453/", "title": "Recount Expected in Virginia's Tight McGuire-Good Race", "body": "The closely watched Virginia GOP primary race pitting House Freedom Caucus Chairman Bob Good against state Sen. John McGuire, the candidate backed by former President Donald Trump and former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, remains too close to call, with watchers saying a vote recount is expected in the 5th Congressional District contest.\n\nThe New York Times reported Thursday that McGuire is holding a tight lead of just 321 votes, with 31,418 votes, over Good, with 31,097 votes. The Times' numbers were updated early Thursday, but were based on tallies reported Wednesday afternoon.\n\nBut even with the few hundred votes separating the candidates, McGuire appeared to be taking a victory lap on X early Wednesday, thanking his family and \"everyone who helped out on this campaign, thank you to the people who endorsed and supported me, and thank you to Donald J. Trump for believing in me. There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory.\"\n\nGood, meanwhile, pointed out in an X post of his own Wednesday that the race \"remains too close to call.\"\n\n\"We are in a period where the law provides a process for evaluating the accuracy of all the vote totals from election day to ensure everyone can have full confidence in the certified results,\" he said. \"Provisional ballots and mail-in ballots are also still to be counted. We are asking for full transparency from the officials involved and patience from the people of the 5th District over the coming weeks as the certification of results is completed. We believe we can still prevail.\"\n\nTrump backed McGuire over Good after the incumbent Republican endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis early on in the GOP presidential primary. McCarthy threw his support behind McGuire after Good voted to oust him from his House speaker role last year.\n\nMeanwhile, considering there are still provisional ballots and postmarked mail-in ballots still coming in by Friday, the race will likely turn into a full recount that could take weeks to determine who will square off against Democrat challenger Gloria Witt in November, reports The Washington Post.\n\nFormer Trump White House adviser Steve Bannon, who backed Good over McGuire, going against Trump's endorsement, said that \"we're not going to know for a month\" who won the race.\n\nHowever, he was quick to label McCarthy and his \"revenge tour\" as a loser in the primaries. McCarthy, R-Calif., pushed to unseat Good and seven other House Republicans who voted to oust him.\n\nMcCarthy has already fallen short in his push to unseat Rep. Nancy Mace, R-S.C., and Bannon said he's been \"humiliated\" in his efforts.\n\nRichmond political analyst Bob Holsworth said the close race between Good and McGuire weakens Trump's endorsement powers.\n\n\"The fact that it was so close suggests that Trump's reach is not as deep and extensive as may have been thought,\" he told The Post.\n\nGood told Newsmax Tuesday, as voters headed to the polls, that he still supports Trump, even though the former president didn't back him.\n\nHe also insisted he was the best choice to help Trump win the White House.\n\n\"We have no choice but to elect him,\" said Good. \"After four years of [Joe] Biden, everybody is doing worse, except the illegal aliens. ... I'll continue to support President Trump and do everything I can to help him get elected and help him win Virginia.\"\n\nMcGuire, however, told Newsmax Tuesday that he's been loyal to Trump since the beginning, unlike Good, who he said \"went around the district trashing Trump, saying he's the only man that could lose to Biden.\"\n\nSandy Fitzgerald \u2709\n\nSandy Fitzgerald has more than three decades in journalism and serves as a general assignment writer for Newsmax covering news, media, and politics.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsMax"}, "authors": {"uri": "8185131632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:39:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:39:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:38:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://roanoke.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/elections/bob-good-john-mcguire-donald-trump/article_c44f515c-78c9-5832-bb1f-051df208a2ec.html", "title": "Good, McGuire primary in 5th District too close to call", "body": "Former President Donald Trump's voice echoed loudly in the 5th District GOP primary Tuesday -- but it was unclear whether it would carry the day for state Sen. John McGuire's bid to unseat Rep. Bob Good, R-5th.\n\nAs of 11:30 p.m., McGuire was up by 327 votes and the contest was too close for the Associated Press to make a call. The bitter rivals had traded the lead back and forth in a contest that had largely revolved around loyalty to the former president.\n\nShortly before midnight, McGuire declared victory, issuing a statement in which he thanked his supporters, including Trump.\n\n\"There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory,\" McGuire said.\n\nGood also thanked supporters in a statement on X, formerly Twitter. He said he is waiting for the complete tally of mail-in ballots and provisional ballots. He said he is working to ensure his campaign has \"teams of observers and legal counsel\" to make sure votes are properly counted in the coming days.\n\n\"The entire DC Swamp was aligned against us with over $10 million in attack ads, but with your help we were able to make this race too close to call,\" Good said. He added: \"No matter the outcome, you've shown the DC Swamp that you won't back down from standing for what's right. Keep the faith and don't stop fighting now.\"\n\nIn Tuesday's low-turnout voting, Virginians picked Democratic and Republican candidates in six of the state's 11 U.S. House districts.\n\nIn some, like the sprawling 5th District, which stretches southwest from Goochland, Louisa, Powhatan and parts of Hanover to the North Carolina line around Danville, the primary winner is odds-on favorite to win the November general election.\n\nWith so many choices in primary races, will Virginia consider ranked choice voting?\n\nIn four Congressional districts, Democratic and Republican candidates faced no intra-party challengers. In the 3rd District, anchored in Newport News, Rep. Bobby Scott, D-3rd, faces only two independents in November.\n\nBut it was the 5th district that attracted the most outside interest, after Trump endorsed McGuire.\n\n\"If he's reelected, Bob Good will stab Virginia in the back sort of like he did with me,\" Trump told a tele-rally for McGuire on the eve of the primary.\n\nGood had endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis for the GOP presidential nomination in April 2023, but then backed Trump after DeSantis dropped out of the race in January of this year.\n\nThe race for the GOP nomination was a highly personalized contest between two conservatives -- one, Good, the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, who voted not to certify President Joe Biden's 2020 election and the other, McGuire, who attended Trump's Jan. 6, 2021, \"Stop the Steal\" rally, but says he did not enter the U.S. Capitol.\n\nMcGuire, a former Navy SEAL, is a three-term member of the House of Delegates who declared his candidacy for Good's congressional seat less than two weeks after his election to the state Senate last year.\n\nSupporters wait and watch\n\nGood had trailed McGuire in the early evening tally, and more than 100 of his supporters who'd gathered for his election party at La Villa, an Italian restaurant in Lynchburg, were tense. Members of the crowd stared at their phones, examining election results and refreshing the page over and over again in hopes their candidate would rally.\n\nJust before 9:30 p.m. their wish came true, at least for the moment, as results showed Good had cut into the lead and made it a one-point race. It was the first time in the evening that the crowd had cheered.\n\nGood had spent most of the night sitting with family, with supporters walking past to offer him words of encouragement. The congressman looked tense, occasionally resting his chin on his left hand, as servers walked through the crowd bringing pizza to customers.\n\nGood campaign manager Diana Shores said she had expected a tight race.\n\n\"But it's still so nerve-racking,\" Shores said.\n\nMcGuire supporters gathered Tuesday night at The Virginian Hotel in downtown Lynchburg, where they were cautiously optimistic as the vote counts from the 24 counties and cities in the 5th District continued to be updated. Among the supporters were Lynchburg Mayor Stephanie Reed and Lynchburg School Board Chair Atul Gupta.\n\nOne voter at the McGuire watch party -- a lifelong Lynchburg area resident -- said he followed Trump's endorsement and voted for McGuire, hoping it will bring harmony to the Republican Party.\n\nAt a June 8 campaign event in Lynchburg for McGuire, Rep. Ryan Zinke, R-Mont., interior secretary under Trump, said he and Trump \"have talked about it long and hard, and we've come to the conclusion that Bob Good is destructive.\"\n\nBesides Trump's endorsement, McGuire campaigned with Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Georgia, while Good has won backing from conservatives including Rep, Matt Gaetz, R-Florida, Sen Rand Paul, R-Kentucky and Steve Bannon a former Trump adviser.\n\nTwo dozen members of the 5th District Republican Congressional Committee sent a letter to Trump in which they praised Good, attacked McGuire and called the endorsement \"ill-advised.\"\n\nGood has called McGuire a \"perpetual candidate\" and argues that he's more conservative because McGuire has won support from allies of the former Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif. Good was one of eight Republicans who voted to oust McCarthy last year.\n\nMcGuire raised more than $1.2 million while Good collected more than $1.1 million, according to the latest financial reports filed with the Federal Elections Commission.\n\nBut the outside spending dwarfed these sums.\n\nSix political action committees have spent $5 million to attack Good or promote McGuire, led by the American Patriots PAC.\n\nNine outside PACs have spent more than $3.4 million to attack McGuire or promote Good, led by the Conservative Outsider and Protect Freedom, a super PAC associated with Paul.\n\n5th District Democrats\n\nDemocrats, meanwhile, selected Gloria Tinsley Witt, of Amherst County, founder of a leadership coaching firm, who prevailed in a three-way contest.\n\nThe district has not elected a Democrat to Congress since 2008, when Tom Perriello edged Rep. Virgil Goode, R-5th, by 727 votes.\n\n1st District Democrats\n\nIn another district touching Richmond's suburbs, the 1st, Leslie C. Mehta defeated Herb Jones, winning 14,734, or 66% of votes cast, to 7,489 or 34%, for Jones, with 95% of precincts reporting unofficial results. She will take on Rep. Rob Wittman, R-1st, who has represented the district since 2007.\n\nA political newcomer, Mehta, the former legal director of the ACLU of Virginia, beat the former New Kent County treasurer, Jones, who tried but failed to unseat Wittman in 2022.\n\n\"I am proud to accept the nomination ... and excited to head on to November because our communities deserve better,\" Mehta said in a post on X.\n\nWittman won in 2022 with 57% of the vote. The district voted 58% to 42%, for Republican Glenn Youngkin in the 2021 contest for governor.\n\nJones was backed by former Gov. Ralph Northam, while Mehta was supported by Rep. Abigail Spanberger, D-7th, as well as by a deep-pocketed Democratic couple, Charlottesville billionaire hedge fund executive Michael Bills and his wife, Sonija Smith.\n\nThis district stretches from parts of Hanover, Henrico and Chesterfield counties to Williamsburg and the Northern Neck.\n\n2nd District Democrats\n\nIn the 2nd District, anchored in Virginia Beach, Navy veteran and nonprofit executive Missy Cotter Smasal won the Democratic nomination, defeating attorney Jake Denton for the right to take on Rep. Jen Kiggans, R-2nd, who is seeking a second term. Smasal received 18,424 votes, or 70%, to Denton's 7,858 votes, or 30%.\n\n\"Thank you to all the voters, volunteers, and donors who have put their faith in me. I'll always have your back,\" Smasal said in a social media post.\n\nRedistricting in 2021 left this district, which includes the Eastern Shore, Suffolk and rural western Tidewater communities in Isle of Wight and Southampton counties, more Republican, though national Democrats have targeted Kiggans seeing a possible pick up here.\n\n7th District\n\nIn Northern Virginia's 7th District, an open seat after Democrat Abigail Spanberger decided not to seek another term in order to run for governor next year, Eugene Vindman captured the Democratic nomination. He bested six other Democrats, with 16,609 votes, or of 49% of the tally, with 97% of precincts reporting unofficial results.\n\nDerrick Anderson a former U.S. Army Green Beret who lost a GOP primary for a Prince William County board seat in 2022, won the GOP nomination. He prevailed in a six-way GOP race with 16,180 votes, or 46% of votes cast.\n\nVindman, who with his twin brother Alexander played a role in Trump's first impeachment, defeated a state legislator, Del. Briana Sewell, D-Prince William and former Del. Elizabeth Guzman, D-Prince William, as well as Prince Willian supervisors Margaret Angela Franklin and Andrea O. Bailey.\n\n\"The stakes of this election couldn't be higher, the passion behind my campaign comes from voters wanting integrity, moderation, and professionalism in a government that works for them; and our grass-roots movement is coming for the extreme MAGA agenda,\" Vindman said in a statement.\n\nAnderson, the GOP nominee, said in a statement: \"I choose a path that takes America back to being the greatest country the world has ever known. A country that is loved by our allies, feared by our enemies, and sought after in every corner of the world.\"\n\nThe district is based in Prince William, Stafford and Spotsylvania counties.\n\n10th District\n\nIn Northern Virginia's 10th District, 12 Democrats and four Republicans sought their parties' nominations for the seat of Rep. Jennifer Wexton, D-10th, who is retiring for health reasons.\n\nState Sen. Suhas Subramanyam, D-Loudon, won with 12,859, or 30% of votes cast, with 96% of precincts reporting unofficial results.\n\nSubramanyam, who received Wexton's endorsement, defeated several other current and former Democratic legislators, including Del. Dan Helmer, D-Fairfax, state Sen. Jennifer Boysko, D-Fairfax, Del. David Reid, D-Loudoun, Del, Michelle Lopes Maldonado, D-Prince William, and former Speaker of the House Eileen Filler-Corn, D-Fairfax.\n\nSubramanyam said in a statement: \"This district is my home. I got married here. My kids were born here. The issues our community faces are personal to our family.\" He added: This district will remain blue.\"\n\nRepublican Mike Clancy, a lawyer and conservative commentator, won the Republican nomination with 64% of votes cast.\n\nThe district is based in Loudoun and Prince William counties.\n\n11th District\n\nIn Fairfax County's 11th Congressional district, longtime Rep Gerry Connolly fended off a challenge from attorney Ahsan Nasar in the Democratic primary. Connolly had 35,894 votes, or 86% of votes cast, to 5,928 or 14% for Nasar, with 98% of votes counted.\n\nDave Ress (804) 649-6948\n\ndress@timesdispatch.com\n\nTimes-Dispatch reporter Michael Martz and Jason Armesto of the Daily Progress contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use {"uri": "8186195276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "02:21:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T02:21:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T02:20:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/mcguire-good-trump-virginia-congress-5th-district/article_b32758ca-7453-5819-b54d-33cd1e3823f2.html", "title": "Experts say Trump's attacks on Good helped McGuire lead in 5th District race", "body": "Former President Donald Trump's attacks on Rep Bob Good, including an election eve virtual rally saying the conservative congressman stabbed him in the back, gave state Sen. John McGuire the push he needed to eke out what's now a tiny lead in Virginia's 5th District, political scientists say.\n\nBut the big question is what McGuire's current 315-vote, 0.5-point margin signifies about the influence of an endorsement from the former president.\n\nTrump-backed McGuire holds slight lead in race with incumbent Bob Good, inside recount margin\n\nWith that close a result, political scientists think a recount is coming.\n\n\"Why did Good make it so close, and perhaps even prevail despite Trump's severe attacks?\" asked John McGlennon, a College of William and Mary political scientist.\n\nLocal electoral boards must still complete their work of checking and doubling-checking Tuesday night's preliminary tallies and count the final mail-in and provisional ballots.\n\nThe 0.5-point gap between McGuire and Good opens the path to a recount, once the boards certify results.\n\nIn a way, the question of Trump's influence comes down to 5th District voters' strong feelings about Washington, government officials and outsiders telling them what to do.\n\n\"It's useful to recognize that for many MAGA voters, Trump's appeal is his willingness to stick it to the establishment,\" McGlennon said.\n\n\"In this race, ironically, the incumbent could proudly point to the Republican establishment's attacks as a sign that he's even more Trump than Trump. Good has that grassroots support that rejects all the party leaders and elected officials ganging up on him because he won't play their game,\" he said.\n\nDuring the campaign, Good made a point of noting that groups close to former Speaker of the House Kevin McCarthy had supported McGuire.\n\nTrump calls in for McGuire on eve of 5th District primary\n\n\"Even Marjorie Taylor Greene became part of the establishment. Look at the lack of turnout for McGuire and Greene on their two-day blitz,\" McGlennon said.\n\nMcGuire's narrow lead shows that that large numbers of 5th district conservatives did not believe that either McGuire or Trump offered a principled reason to abandon Good, while McCarthy allies' support for McGuire was another reason to stick to Good, said longtime Virginia analyst Bob Holsworth, a former VCU dean.\n\n\"The vast majority of Good voters will cast a ballot for Trump in November. But for Trump to be competitive in Virginia, he will need a huge turnout in the parts of the district that supported Good. The open question is whether the enthusiasm level that drives turnout will be as high as he need,\" Holsworth said.\n\nRoanoke College political scientist Harry Wilson said Trump's impact is obvious.\n\n\"In an election this close, you can point to a variety of factors, but I seriously doubt McGuire would have won, assuming he does, without Trump's endorsement. Kevin McCarthy may have a fingerprint on it as well,\" Wilson said.\n\n\"Maybe some folks were tired of Good's style. Maybe folks actually like McGuire. Some may still be smarting over Good defeating [Denver] Riggleman,\" Wilson said, referring to the Republican who represented the district for one term before Good defeated him in a 2020 nominating convention after Riggleman officiated a same-sex marriage and drew fire for his stands on immigration and fiscal policy.\n\nStill, it was Trump who swung the election for McGuire, said Stephen Farnsworth, a political scientist at the University of Mary Washington.\n\n\"If the former president had not weighed in against Good, the incumbent would have been renominated in a walk,\" Farnsworth said. \"His combative brand of conservatism fits well with the preferences of Republican primary voters in the district.\"\n\nGood's bad luck was an early endorsement last year of Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis' short-lived bid to challenge Trump for the GOP's presidential nomination, Farnsworth said.\n\n\"Trump personalizes politics at every opportunity. If Good had made the politically savvy choice of backing Trump from the start, rather than endorsing DeSantis, he wouldn't be on the knife's edge of losing this renomination,\" he added.\n\nCao wins GOP nomination for US Senate, will take on Kaine\n\nEd Lynch, chairman of Hollins University's global politics and societies department, said McGuire probably would not have received much more than 30% of the vote without Trump's support.\n\n\"To my mind, there is no question that the only way to put up a serious primary challenge to a rock-ribbed conservative like Bob Good was with an endorsement by Donald Trump,\" he said.\n\nEarly voting offers a key clue to Trump's influence, political scientists say.\n\nGood won 5,822 early votes to McGuire's 5,012, but McGuire had a 943-vote edge with Election Day ballots, according to unofficial state Department of Election tallies. All in all, once mail-in ballots already counted are included, McGuire won 31,370 votes to Good's 31,055.\n\n\"The early voting numbers demonstrated that Good's appeal remained stronger until Trump ramped up his attacks on the Republican incumbent in recent days over what Trump viewed as Good's disloyalty,\" Farnsworth said.\n\nThose attacks included the virtual rally on Monday evening during which Trump declared: \"If he's reelected, Bob Good will stab Virginia in the back sort of like he did with me.\"\n\nThe primary saw some big spending, much of it from outsiders. All in all, the sums spent will likely exceed $15 million from the two campaigns themselves and outside independent committees, with more backing McGuire and attacking Good, McGlennon said.\n\nTurnout was big, as well, with more than 62,000 voting, nearly double the turnout in the busiest of Virginia's eight other House primaries.\n\n\"Turnout was huge in the 5th because you had two combative candidates who were roughly evenly matched,\" said Farnsworth. \"The margin was far closer than in any of the other congressional primary contests in Virginia on Tuesday, and there was huge campaign spending dropped into this race from national Republicans.\"\n\nGood beat McGuire in his Lynchburg-area home base, racking up margins as high at 56% and 59% of votes cast, and also led in the Charlottesville area. McGuire won 60%-plus margins in the parts of the district nearest Richmond, including his Goochland County home as well as Louisa, Powhatan and parts of Hanover counties.\n\nA blow to Bob: Trump endorsement could tilt 5th District GOP primary in John McGuire's favor\n\n\"I wouldn't read anything into this race carrying over to November, but the polls, including Roanoke College, suggest the general election will be much closer than 2020,\" Wilson said.\n\nThe real message from the 5th District may be how the presidential campaigns interpret the 5th when they start allocating resources to different states, Wilson said.\n\nAnd Trump gave one clue at the McGuire virtual rally, when he said he would \"put a very heavy play on Virginia,\" adding, \"I think we're gonna win the state of Virginia.\"\n\nTrump's other big Virginia endorsement, of retired Navy Capt. Hung Cao's bid to challenge Sen. Tim Kaine, shows the former president's strength among Virginia Republicans, Hollins' Lynch said. Cao won a five-way race with 62% of votes cast.\n\n\"That race could have gone right down to the wire had Trump stayed out of it,\" Lynch said.\n\n\"I still rate the commonwealth as safe for the Democrats in the Senate, but not solid,\" Lynch said.\n\n\"Ironically, the better Trump does in Virginia, the better for Kaine. Reluctant Trump voters, who are voting for Trump simply because they can't stand Biden, will want to balance that uncomfortable vote with a much more comfortable vote for Kaine,\" he added.\n\nCao began the race last year with an advantage from name recognition in his competitive race against Democratic U.S. Rep. Jennifer Wexton of Virginia's 10th, which he lost by 6.5 percentage points.\n\nTrump's endorsement \"may have bumped him from being just a favorite to a landslide winner,\" Larry Sabato, president of the Center for Politics at the University of Virginia, said in an analysis.\n\nThe former president \"probably knew he had a winning choice,\" said Mark Rozell, dean of the Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University. \"He likes to run up the number of Trump-endorsed candidates who won in order to show he had control of the party apparatus across the country.\"\n\nTrump's presence was felt in the Democratic primary in Northern Virginia's 7th District, where Eugene Vindman won a 49% plurality in a seven-way race that featured four current or former officeholders in the district.\n\nIt was Vindman's first political race, but he benefited from national name recognition because of the role that he and his twin brother, Alexander, played in the first impeachment of Trump.\n\nHe ran on a message of protecting democracy that invoked Trump's efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election.\n\nThe winner of the GOP primary, Derrick Anderson, told supporters, \"Eugene Vindman is only running for revenge -- revenge against Donald Trump and revenge against Republicans.\"\n\nDemocratic U.S. Rep. Abigail Spanberger won the swing district two years ago after a new political map moved it from the Richmond suburbs to Northern Virginia and Fredericksburg. Spanberger, who lives in Henrico County, is running for governor next year instead of a fourth term in Congress.\n\nIn his victory statement, Vindman tried to link Anderson to Trump's Make America Great Again supporters, \"who wants nothing more than to play politics with our classrooms and let politicians ban books on the holocaust and slavery and throw them into the fire.\"\n\n\"Running as a MAGA Republican would put him [Anderson] at odds with the vast majority of voters in the district,\" he said. \"You don't go from Spanberger to MAGA candidate in one election cycle.\"\n\nA political endorsement may have been decisive in Sen. Suhas Subramanyam's victory in a 12-person race in the 10th District Democratic primary, but it wasn't Trump's. Wexton, who is stepping down because of a serious medical condition, endorsed Subramanyam as her preferred successor, emphasizing his roots in Loudoun County, with more than half of the registered voters in the district.\n\nWhile other congressional races have been largely national in message, Rozell said Subramanyam's ties to Loudoun and emphasis on local issues gave him an advantage over Democratic Del. Dan Helmer of Fairfax, who had raised the most money in the race but lived just outside of the district.\n\n\"He had a geographical challenge,\" Rozell said.\n\nSubramanyam won the race with a 30% plurality and a margin of less than 1,500 votes over Helmer.\n\nDave Ress (804) 649-6948\n\ndress@timesdispatch.com\n\nMichael Martz (804) 649-6964\n\nmmartz@timesdispatch.com\n\nBe the first to {"uri": "8184567523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:14:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:14:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:13:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2987602-high-stakes-virginia-primary-tight-race-between-bob-good-and-john-mcguire", "title": "High-Stakes Virginia Primary: Tight Race Between Bob Good and John McGuire | Politics", "body": "The primary race between U.S. Representative Bob Good and challenger John McGuire remains too close to call. McGuire led slightly with 92% of votes counted. Good, a hardline House Republican, faced backlash from both Trump and moderate Republicans. The district is strongly Republican, favoring the primary winner in November.\n\nThe race between U.S. Representative Bob Good, a prominent hardline House Republican, and a primary challenger backed by both Donald Trump and a key group of moderate Republicans, remained too close to call on Tuesday night. The winner of the contest between Good, chair of the House Freedom Caucus, and former Navy SEAL John McGuire is expected to easily carry the strongly Republican-leaning southern Virginia district in the Nov. 5 election, when control of the White House and both chambers of Congress will be up for grabs.\n\nVirginia state laws allow for a recount if results are within one percentage point. McGuire led Good by 0.4% - less than 300 votes - with 92% of votes counted, according to the Associated Press at time of publication. Good angered former President Trump by endorsing Florida Governor Ron DeSantis in his Republican presidential primary campaign against Trump, switching his endorsement to Trump only after DeSantis dropped out.\n\nGood also ignited the ire of moderate Republicans after he voted to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his role in October, launching weeks of chaos and bitter, highly public infighting as Republicans attempted to coalesce around a replacement. Trump endorsed Good's challenger McGuire, a Virginia state senator, in a May social media post. Defending Main Street, the super PAC affiliated with the moderate Republican Main Street Caucus, has spent $600,000 on ads to defeat Good.\n\n\"He's a Republican in name only,\" Sarah Chamberlain, CEO of the Republican Main Street Partnership, the nonprofit organization affiliated with the caucus, said. The group does not normally work to oust incumbents, she said, calling Good \"a unique situation\" after he campaigned against moderate Republican colleagues and voted against Republican bills on the House floor. Following Trump's endorsement of McGuire, Good said in a statement, \"I have never been the choice of political power brokers in Washington.\"\n\nDEMOCRATS NOMINATE CANDIDATES Virginia Democrats and Republicans will also pick candidates on Tuesday to vie for the seats currently held by Democratic U.S. Representatives Jennifer Wexton and Abigail Spanberger, both elected in 2018 when their party won control of the House for the second half of Trump's term.\n\nThe districts could also play an important role in Democrats' efforts to win back a House majority in November. In Virginia's 7th district, Eugene Vindman, the brother of Alexander Vindman, who played an important role in Trump's first impeachment, was projected by the Associated Press to win the Democratic nomination for Spanberger's seat, which she is leaving to run for governor.\n\nDerrick Anderson, a former Green Beret, beat Cameron Hamilton, a former NAVY Seal, for the Republican nomination in the competitive district where many military families live, according to the Associated Press. In Virginia's 10th district, state Senator Democratic Suhas Subramanyam edged out a win in a crowded race to succeed the retiring Wexton, who endorsed him in May. The winner of Tuesday's primary is strongly favored to win the heavily Democratic district in November.\n\nPolls closed in Virginia at 7 p.m. (2300 GMT).\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-394149997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:40:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:40:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T02:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://dailyprogress.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/elections/bob-good-john-mcguire-donald-trump/article_da9173a1-fbf3-53ec-99b2-7df7c16cb30b.html", "title": "Good, McGuire primary in Virginia's 5th District too close to call", "body": "Former President Donald Trump's voice echoed loudly in the 5th District GOP primary Tuesday -- but as of press time it was unclear whether it would carry the day for state Sen. John McGuire's bid to unseat U.S. Rep. Bob Good.\n\nAs of press time, McGuire was up by fewer than 300 votes and the contest was too close for the Associated Press to make a call. The bitter rivals had traded the lead back and forth in a contest that had largely revolved around loyalty to the former president.\n\nElections\n\nTrump calls in for McGuire on eve of 5th District primary\n\nDAVE RESS Richmond Times-Dispatch\n\nIn Tuesday's low-turnout voting, Virginians picked Democratic and Republican candidates in six of the state's 11 U.S. House districts.\n\nIn some, like the sprawling 5th District, which stretches southwest from Goochland, Louisa, Powhatan and parts of Hanover to the North Carolina line around Danville, the primary winner is the odds-on favorite to win the November general election.\n\nIn four congressional districts, Democratic and Republican candidates faced no intraparty challengers. In the 3rd District, anchored in Newport News, Democratic U.S. Rep. Bobby Scott faces only two independents in November.\n\nBut it was the 5th District that attracted the most outside interest, after Trump endorsed McGuire.\n\n\"If he's reelected, Bob Good will stab Virginia in the back sort of like he did with me,\" Trump told a virtual rally for McGuire on the eve of the primary.\n\nGood had endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis for the GOP presidential nomination in April 2023, but then backed Trump after DeSantis dropped out of the race in January of this year.\n\nThe race for the GOP nomination was a highly personalized contest between two conservatives: one Good, the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus who voted not to certify President Biden's election, and the other McGuire, who admittedly attended Trump's Jan. 6, 2021, \"Stop the Steal\" rally the day before the certification vote. McGuire has said he did not enter the U.S. Capitol during the riot that ensued.\n\nMcGuire, a former Navy SEAL, is a three-term member of the House of Delegates who declared his candidacy for Good's congressional seat less than two weeks after his election to the state Senate last year despite telling voters he was dedicated to serving in the state house.\n\nGood had trailed McGuire in the early evening tally, and more than 100 of his supporters who'd gathered for his election party at La-Villa, an Italian restaurant in Lynchburg, were tense. Members of the crowd stared at their phones, examining election results and refreshing the page over and over again in hopes their candidate would rally.\n\nJust before 9:30 p.m. their wish came true at least for the moment, as results showed Good had cut into the lead and made it a one-point race. It was the first time in the evening that the crowd cheered.\n\nGood spent most of the night sitting with family, supporters walking past to offer him words of encouragement. The congressman looked tense, occasionally resting his chin on his left hand, as servers walked through the crowd bringing pizza to customers.\n\nGood campaign manager Diana Shores said she had expected a tight race.\n\n\"But it's still so nerve-racking,\" Shores said.\n\nThe race split Republican leaders nationwide. McGuire campaigned with U.S. Rep Marjorie Taylor Greene, while Good won the backing of Rep. Matt Gaetz of Florida, Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky and former Trump adviser Steve Bannon.\n\nTwo dozen members of the 5th District Republican Congressional Committee sent a letter to Trump in which they praised Good, attacked McGuire and called his endorsement of the latter \"ill-advised.\"\n\nGood has called McGuire a \"perpetual candidate\" who lacks his conservative bona fides, seeing as how McGuire was supported by former allies of former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Good was one of eight Republicans who voted to oust McCarthy last year.\n\nMcGuire raised more than $1.2 million, while Good collected more than $1.1 million, according to the latest financial reports filed with the Federal Elections Commission.\n\nBut the outside spending dwarfed these sums.\n\nSix political action committees have spent $5 million to attack Good or promote McGuire, led by the American Patriots PAC.\n\nNine outside PACs have spent more than $3.4 million to attack McGuire or promote Good, led by the Conservative Outsider and Protect Freedom, a super PAC associated with Paul.\n\nMeanwhile, Democrats on Tuesday nominated Gloria Tinsley Witt, a leadership coach and head of the Amherst County NAACP, who prevailed in a three-way contest.\n\nThe district has not elected a Democrat to Congress since 2008, when Charlottesville's Tom Perriello edged Rep. Virgil Goode of Rocky Mount by 727 votes.\n\nTimes-Dispatch reporter Michael Martz and Daily Progress reporter Jason Armesto contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "dailyprogress.com", {"uri": "8185272675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:08:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:08:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:07:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-virginia-gop-primary-john-mcguire-bob-good-1914672", "title": "Donald Trump's influence over GOP stung by Virginia election surprise", "body": "Former President Donald Trump's influence on the election in Virginia's 5th Congressional District may not have been as significant as he would have liked, as the Republican primary race is still too close to call.\n\nWith 98 percent of the ballots counted, the Associated Press reported, state Senator John McGuire, whom Trump has endorsed, led incumbent Representative Bob Good by just 327 votes (50.3 percent to 49.7 percent). The remaining votes are not expected to be counted on Wednesday as Virginia observes the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nIf the margin of victory between the candidates is less than 1 percent, the race -- which has not been called by the AP or other prominent news outlets -- could head to a recount.\n\nThe Cook Political Report, an independent publication for election analysis, cited Trump's endorsement of McGuire as the reason Good is considered one of the GOP incumbents most vulnerable to losing their candidacy before November's elections.\n\nAs Good and McGuire remain neck and neck, it seems Trump's influence on primary elections may not have the pull it once did.\n\nTrump has often cited his record of endorsing candidates who go on to win their respective races as a sign of his influence and power over the Republican Party.\n\nWhile the former president has urged Republican primary voters to support McGuire over Good -- who has also been targeted by establishment Republicans and super PACs after being one of eight GOP lawmakers who voted to oust Kevin McCarthy as House speaker in October -- the incumbent could still win Virginia's 5th Congressional District.\n\nIf Good manages to win the race, it will be the third time in recent weeks that a Trump-backed candidate has lost their election.\n\nOn May 28, Texas House Speaker Dade Phelan narrowly defeated David Covey, his Trump-endorsed challenger, in the primary runoff for the state's District 21.\n\nThough the GOP primary election for Virginia's 5th Congressional District has not been called, McGuire declared himself the victor Tuesday night.\n\nOn X, formerly Twitter, McGuire wrote, \"There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory.\"\n\nIn his own statement on the social media platform, Good thanked his supporters and said he was waiting for the final election results.\n\n\"The entire DC Swamp was aligned against us with over $10 million in attack ads, but with your help we were able to make this race too close to call,\" he wrote on X.\n\nGood continued: \"We implemented the best early voting operation that the 5th District has ever seen, and we are still waiting for the results of mail-in ballots and provisional ballots. We are doing what we can to ensure we have teams of observers and legal counsel to ensure all the votes are properly counted in the coming days.\"\n\nTrump endorsed McGuire over Good after the congressman backed Florida Governor Ron DeSantis over the former president in the 2024 Republican presidential primary.\n\nGood later switched allegiances to Trump after DeSantis ended his White House bid in January. Trump described Good's endorsement as being \"too late,\" saying the \"damage had been done.\"\n\n\"I just want to MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN, and the person that can most help me do that is Navy Seal and highly respected State Legislator, John McGuire, a true American Hero,\" Trump wrote on Truth Social.\n\nHe added: \"John, who fought the Cartels on the Front Line, and then came home and fought the drug dealers in Virginia, will ALWAYS PUT AMERICA FIRST.\"", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ewan_palmer@newsweek.com", "name":
