{"uri": "8185487420", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:31:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:31:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:30:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://foxwilmington.com/politics/trump-and-mccarthy-sought-revenge-against-top-house-conservative-but-gop-primary-too-close-to-call/", "title": "Trump and McCarthy sought revenge against top House conservative, but GOP primary too close to call | Fox Wilmington WSFX-TV", "body": "It is a nail-biter in Virginia's 5th Congressional District as one of the nation's most conservative members of Congress is fighting for his political life against a primary challenger backed by former President Trump and former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy.\n\nRep. Bob Good, who chairs the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, trailed primary challenger state Sen. John McGuire by 327 votes as of 12 a.m. Wednesday morning, according to unofficial returns in the GOP nomination race in the reliably red southern Virginia district.\n\nVirginia observes the Juneteenth holiday, and a resumption of the vote tabulation for the remaining uncounted ballots in the race may not take place until Thursday. The current margin in the election is less than one percent and if it remains under that level, the race would qualify for a recount according to Virginia law.\n\nFOX NEWS POLL: BIDEN, TRUMP IN A DEAD HEAT IN VIRGINIA\n\nGood, who is running for a third term in Congress, aims to avert becoming the first House incumbent this election cycle to be ousted by a primary challenger, in a contentious intra-party primary battle that pitted conservatives versus conservatives and Trump against some of his biggest allies in the House of Representatives.\n\n\"We need leaders that know how to put petty differences aside and bring people together for a better future,\" McGuire, a former Navy SEAL, told supporters on Tuesday night. \"And that's what I'm all about.\"\n\nHEAD HERE FOR THE LATEST FOX NEWS PRIMARY RESULTS\n\nHis comments came as he prematurely declared victory in a speech at his election party in Lynchburg, Virginia.\n\nGood did not give a speech at his primary night gathering, which was also held in Lynchburg, but in a social media post he noted that \"we're still waiting on the final election results.\"\n\nIn a race where a whopping $14 million was spent - with much of it targeting the incumbent - Good wrote that \"no matter the outcome, you've shown the DC Swamp that you won't back down from standing for what's right. Keep the faith and don't stop fighting now.\"\n\nGood incurred Trump's wrath for being one of just a handful of House Republicans to endorse Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the GOP presidential primaries.\n\nEven though Good avoided criticizing Trump and quickly endorsed the former president after DeSantis ended his White House bid in January, Trump wrote on this Truth Social platform that \"the damage has been done!\"\n\nThe former president last month endorsed McGuire, who also had the backing of Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia, a conservative firebrand and major Trump ally who is a vocal critic of Good who last year broke with the House Freedom Caucus. The group is considered the most far-right organization of lawmakers in the chamber.\n\nMcCarthy also targeted Good, who was one of eight Republicans last autumn who joined with Democrats to vote to oust McCarthy from his leadership position.\n\nGood had the support of Reps. Matt Gaetz and Byron Donalds of Florida, two conservatives who are also strong backers of Trump.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nFellow House Freedom Caucus members, Reps. Chip Roy of Texas and Andy Biggs of Arizona, joined Good in Virginia for a rally on Friday.\n\nEven though he was targeted by Trump, Good spotlighted his support for the former president as he ran for re-election.\n\n\"Happy Birthday to the best and next president of the United States, President Trump!\" Good wrote on social media on Friday, which was the former president's 78th birthday.\n\nGood {"uri": "8186040991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:54:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:54:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.wtaj.com/hill-politics/bob-goods-house-antagonists-take-victory-lap-over-virginia-primary/", "title": "Bob Good's House antagonists take victory lap over Virginia primary", "body": "Republicans who campaigned against House Freedom Caucus Chair Bob Good (R-Va.) in his primary against state Sen. John McGuire are seeing the race as a victory, even as it remains too close to call.\n\nWith bitter anger about Good's vote to yank away former Speaker Kevin McCarthy's (R-Calif.) gavel in large part fueling the opposition to him, those who worked against Good say the race should serve as a warning against the kind of tactics, style and demeanor that contributed to discord in the House.\n\n\"He represented, for many of us, what was wrong with this Congress, the dysfunction. And he was sort of part of the soul of it -- the seed of all this dysfunction,\" said Rep. Don Bacon (R-Neb.), who endorsed McGuire.\n\n\"Is it conservative to shut down government? I don't think it is,\" Bacon said. \"What does conservative mean? I think the way he went about it by trying to dethrone, you know, McCarthy -- he did -- and all the other shenanigans this year, I don't think that's conservative.\"\n\nTo be sure, former President Trump's endorsement of McGuire after Good initially endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the GOP presidential primary played a key role in the outcome. But Good's detractors in the House point to the support -- and money -- McGuire got that stemmed from anger about McCarthy and Good's political choices as having played a large part in the race.\n\nStill, the race is not final.\n\nMcGuire led Good by 307 votes -- or 0.4 percent -- as of Wednesday afternoon, according to Decision Desk HQ, which reported 95 percent of the vote in. The election is at a standstill for now: Votes are not expected to be tallied Wednesday, Juneteenth, which Virginia observes, according to The Associated Press.\n\nEven so, the race is likely headed for a recount: In the Old Dominion, candidates can request a recount if the margin is less than 1 percent.\n\nGood, for his part, is keeping the faith, calling the race \"too close to call,\" warning that counting can stretch on for weeks, and expressing a strong sense of optimism that the tally could flip in his direction.\n\n\"We believe we can still prevail,\" he wrote on social platform X.\n\nMcGuire, however, sees the race differently. The former Navy SEAL declared victory Tuesday night, telling the crowd at his victory party, \"It is an honor to be your Republican nominee.\"\n\n\"There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory,\" he echoed in a post on X early Wednesday morning.\n\nA number of McGuire's supporters followed with celebrations for McGuire on social media, including Bacon and Rep. Ryan Zinke (R-Mont.). Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.), who also supported McCarthy and was removed from the Freedom Caucus last year after clashes with members, called Good \"toxic\" as she congratulated McGuire in a post on X.\n\n\"I hope he's right,\" Bacon said of McGuire's victory lap coming before the race was called. \"Talking to other people in Virginia right now, they're pretty confident.\"\n\nSarah Chamberlain, the president and CEO of the Republican Main Street Partnership, said she hopes that the uprising against Good gives other members pause before using the kind of tactics that he used. Defending Main Street, her group's affiliated super PAC, spent $452,000 on ads supporting McGuire.\n\n\"He votes against Republican bills. He also votes Republican rules, so we don't even get the bills to the floor,\" Chamberlain said of Good, referring to procedural votes that are normally party-line measures but that Good and other Republicans have used to protest bills.\n\n\"It wasn't as much about Kevin McCarthy as it was like, listen, can't have Republican members voting with the Democrats to take down Republican initiatives,\" Chamberlain said.\n\nGood is only the second incumbent Republican that Defending Main Street has campaigned against in a primary, with former Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa) being the first in 2020.\n\nGood's endorsements of challengers to other incumbent Republicans earlier in the year also inspired support for McGuire. Bacon endorsed McGuire in large part because Good backed his more hard-line conservative challenger who fell short of unseating the incumbent by 24 percentage points.\n\n\"This is a little bit about ideology, I think, but more of it was how Bob Good treated people. He was sort of just obnoxiously rude,\" Bacon said.\n\nMcGuire is not the Republican who would usually be lumped in with moderates like Bacon. He attended the \"Stop the Steal\" rally at the Capitol on Jan. 6 -- but did not go into the Capitol -- and has defended doing so, saying Tuesday on CNN that \"Trump was robbed.\"\n\nBut if GOP members who supported the Virginia state senator hope that it will change how hard-line conservatives in the conference act, they will have to hope that their colleagues discount other major takeaways from the race.\n\nGood supporters could argue that the results in the race -- albeit still pending -- reflect a strong showing and outperformance of expectations in the face of so much opposition.\n\nA June 2-4 poll commissioned by the conservative Virginia Faith and Freedom Coalition found McGuire with a 10-point lead over Good -- a far cry from the half-percentage point that separates them in the current vote tally. Twenty-nine percent of poll respondents were undecided.\n\nGood was also out-spent on the airwaves; the ad tracking firm AdImpact found $9 million was spent on ads in support of McGuire or opposed to the incumbent, compared to $5.6 million worth that was supportive of Good or opposed to McGuire.\n\nPerhaps most important is the influence of Trump.\n\nRep. Tim Burchett (R-Tenn.), another one of the eight Republicans who had moved to oust McCarthy, said that McGuire's strong showing, and potential victory, was due to Trump's backing more than anything else.\n\n\"It 100% has to do with Trump,\" Burchett said. \"The President is very, very strong, especially in the grassroots. That carries a lot of weight.\"\n\nRep. Nancy Mace (R-S.C.), another Republican who voted to oust McCarthy, prevailed in her primary last week despite McCarthy and his allies supporting her opponent in the first stop on his \"revenge\" primary tour against those who voted to remove him. Mace had the support, importantly, of Trump.\n\nBurchett is not facing a primary challenger this year, though he said that did not stop his antagonists from trying to find one.\n\nStill, Burchett said that the support for Good from those who did not like his tactics and style are not dissuading him from voting how he wants to.\n\n\"I knew it could possibly cost me my job,\" Burchett said of his vote to remove McCarthy, \"but I still think it was the right decision to make at the time.\"", "source": {"uri": "wtaj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTAJ - www.wtaj.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184687182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:19:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:19:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:19:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/politics/2024/06/18/trump-backed-john-mcguire-leads-tooclosetocall-virginia-primary-rep-bob-good/", "title": "Trump-Backed John McGuire Leads in Too-Close-to-Call Virginia Primary", "body": "Trump-backed Virginia State Sen. John McGuire (R) appears to be leading Virginia's 5th Congressional District race against Rep. Bob Good (R-VA), although the race remains too close to call.\n\nHours after the polls have closed, Good and McGuire remain in a close race, with McGuire receiving 31,411 votes, or 50.3 percent of the vote. Good was reported to have received 31,084 votes, or 49.7 percent, according to the Associated Press (AP).\n\nWhile the race is still too close to call officially, McGuire declared victory on Tuesday evening just before midnight saying he is confident that the remaining votes will break his way.\n\n\"My life is a testament to the fact that America is the greatest country on this planet and I'm so honored to have the chance to serve her again,\" McGuire said in a statement. \"Thank you to my family, thank you to everyone who helped out on this campaign, thank you to the people who endorsed and supported me, and thank you to Donald J. Trump for believing in me. There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory.\"\n\nMcGuire added that \"folks in the 5th District can rest assured that they should\" elect him in the upcoming November election.\n\n\"They will have an effective fighter in Congress who will get the job done for them,\" McGuire added. \"I look forward to working with Trump to beat Joe Biden in November and pass Trump's agenda in Congress. Trump and McGuire will Make America Great Again!\"\n\nFelicity Taylor, a reporter with CBS19 News wrote in a post on X that McGuire was set to address a crowd of people, while Good had reportedly left his election party without addressing members of the media.\n\nGood wrote in a post on X that as they awaited \"the final results of today's primary,\" he \"wanted to thank\" the voters for their support.\n\n\"You made sure your vote was cast,\" Good wrote. \"many of you gave up your precious time to make phone calls and knock on doors. Several of you had tough conversations to ensure people knew the truth about this race. You encouraged your family, friends, and church members to get out and vote. And some of you worked the polls for hours to hand out literature.\"\n\nGood added that \"most\" of his campaign had been \"made up of small donations given by thousands,\" who believed in him and his campaign.\n\nDave Wasserman reported that \"it's fair to say McGuire (R), who leads Good (R) by 327 votes with 1,532 early votes left to count in Bedford and Fluvanna\" counties, could be a \"slight favorite.\"\n\nFormer President Donald Trump issued an endorsement of McGuire on May 28 in which he slammed Good as being \"BAD FOR VIRGINIA, AND BAD FOR THE USA.\"\n\nTrump stated that Good \"turned his back on our incredible movement, and was constantly attacking and fighting\" with the former president until he gave Trump a \"warm and 'loving' Endorsement.\"\n\n\"But really, it was too late,\" Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social. \"The damage had been done!\"\n\nGood initially supported Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R) in his bid for the Republican nomination for president, even after Trump had endorsed Good in his primary race last year.\n\n\"I'm not against President Trump - I like what President Trump did,\" Good explained to reporters in January. \"I just think we need eight years and so that's why I endorsed Gov. DeSantis.\"", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breitbart"}, "authors": [{"uri": "elizabeth_weibel@breitbart.com", "name": "Elizabeth Weibel", "type": "author", "https://media.breitbart.com/media/2024/06/virginia-5th-John-McGuire-June-15-2024-file-getty.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9661234", "eventUri": "eng-9661234", "location": {"type": "textEnd": 2584}], "sentiment": 0.5058823529411764, "wgt": 182, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8184545799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "02:47:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T02:47:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T02:46:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://richmond.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/bob-good-john-mcguire-donald-trump/article_c3bb2670-2dc1-11ef-9db2-07f473ab96eb.html", "title": "Good, McGuire primary in 5th District too close to call", "body": "Dave Ress\n\nFormer President Donald Trump's voice echoed loudly in the 5th District GOP primary Tuesday - but it was unclear whether it would carry the day for state Sen. John McGuire's bid to unseat Rep. Bob Good, R-5th.\n\nAs of press time, McGuire was up by fewer than 300 votes and the contest was too close for the Associated Press to make a call. The bitter rivals had traded the lead back and forth in a contest that had largely revolved around loyalty to the former president.\n\nIn Tuesday's low-turnout voting, Virginians picked Democratic and Republican candidates in six of the state's 11 U.S. House districts.\n\nIn some, like the sprawling 5th District, which stretches southwest from Goochland, Louisa, Powhatan and parts of Hanover to the North Carolina line around Danville, the primary winner is odds-on favorite to win the November general election.\n\nPeople are also reading... Virginia ABC lays off 25 as it prepares for independent future These companies top list of Richmond eviction filers, public records show Effort to ban kratom in Virginia sparks uproar Virginia swimmer Gretchen Walsh breaks world record in 100-meter butterfly Virginia's Elijah Gertrude will miss season after scooter wreck This new wine bar is in a former Henrico barber shop State pulls Ferrum College lab school application; president says no explanation offered Sources: Virginia, Tony Bennett working on long-term deal for basketball coach Henrico man killed in crash on Route 288 in Chesterfield Police: Man shot dead near Byrd Park Petersburg schools' acting superintendent resigns weeks after taking over Chesterfield schools employee charged with possessing child porn New restaurant Centro headed to Midlothian UPDATE: Police identify victim of Henrico homicide Hanover considers ending membership with Virginia School Boards Association With so many choices in primary races, will Virginia consider ranked choice voting?\n\nIn four Congressional districts, Democratic and Republican candidates faced no intra-party challengers. In the 3rd District, anchored in Newport News, Rep. Bobby Scott, D-3rd, faces only two independents in November.\n\nBut it was the 5th district that attracted the most outside interest, after Trump endorsed McGuire.\n\n\"If he's reelected, Bob Good will stab Virginia in the back sort of like he did with me,\" Trump told a tele-rally for McGuire on the eve of the primary.\n\nGood had endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis for the GOP presidential nomination in April 2023, but then backed Trump after DeSantis dropped out of the race in January of this year.\n\nThe race for the GOP nomination was a highly personalized contest between two conservatives - one, Good, the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, who voted not to certify President Joe Biden's election and the other, McGuire, attended Trump's Jan. 6, 2021, \"Stop the Steal\" rally the day before the certification vote, but says he did not enter the U.S. Capitol.\n\nMcGuire, a former Navy SEAL, is a three-term member of the House of Delegates who declared his candidacy for Good's congressional seat less than two weeks after his election to the state Senate last year.\n\nGood had trailed McGuire in the early evening tally, and more than 100 of his supporters who'd gathered for his election party at La-Villa, an Italian restaurant in Lynchburg, were tense. Members of the crowd stared at their phones, examining election results and refreshing the page over and over again in hopes their candidate would rally.\n\nJust before 9:30 p.m. their wish came true at least for the moment, as results showed Good had cut into the lead and made it a one-point race. It was the first time in the evening that the crowd had cheered, their hopes of Good returning to office\n\nGood had spent most of the night sitting with family, with supporters walking past to offer him words of encouragement. The congressman looked tense, occasionally resting his chin on his left hand, as servers walked through the crowd bringing pizza to customers.\n\nGood campaign manager Diana Shores said she had expected a tight race.\n\n\"But it's still so nerve-racking,\" Shores said.\n\nBesides Trump's endorsement, McGuire campaigned with Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Georgia, while Good has won backing from conservatives including Rep, Matt Gaetz, R-Florida, Sen Rand Paul, R-Kentucky and Steve Bannon.\n\nTwo dozen members of the 5th District Republican Congressional Committee sent a letter to Trump in which they praised Good, attacked McGuire and called the endorsement \"ill-advised.\"\n\nGood has called McGuire a \"perpetual candidate\" and argues that he's more conservative because McGuire has won support from allies of the former Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif. Good was one of eight Republicans who voted to oust McCarthy last year.\n\nMcGuire raised more than $1.2 million while Good collected more than $1.1 million, according to the latest financial reports filed with the Federal Elections Commission.\n\nBut the outside spending dwarfed these sums.\n\nSix political action committees have spent $5 million to attack Good or promote McGuire, led by the American Patriots PAC.\n\nNine outside PACs have spent more than $3.4 million to attack McGuire or promote Good, led by the Conservative Outsider and Protect Freedom, a super PAC associated with Paul.\n\n5th District Democrats\n\nDemocrats, meanwhile, selected Gloria Tinsley Witt, of Amherst, founder of a leadership coaching firm, who prevailed in a three-way contest.\n\nThe district has not elected a Democrat to Congress since 2008, when Tom Perriello edged Rep. Virgil Goode, R-5th by 727 votes, though its 24 cities and counties include strongly Democratic Charlottesville.\n\n1st District Democrats\n\nIn another district touching Richmond's suburbs, the 1st, Leslie C. Mehta defeated Herb Jones, winning 12,393, or 68% of votes cast to 5,883 or 32%, with 93% of precincts reporting unofficial results. She will take on Rep. Rob Wittman, R-1st, who has represented the district since 2007.\n\nA political newcomer, Mehta, the former legal director of the ACLU of Virginia, beat the former New Kent County treasurer, Jones, who tried but failed to unseat Wittman in 2022.\n\n\"I am proud to accept the nomination... and excited to head on to November because our communities deserve better,\" Mehta said in a tweet on X (formerly known as Twitter).\n\nWittman won in 2022 with 57% of the vote. The district voted 58% to 42%, for Republican Glenn Youngkin in the 2021 contest for governor.\n\nJones was backed by former Gov. Ralph Northam, while Mehta was supported by Rep. Abigail Spanberger, D-7th, as well as by a deep-pocketed Democratic couple, Charlottesville billionaire hedge fund executive Michael Bills and his wife, Sonija Smith.\n\nThis district stretches from parts of Hanover, Henrico and Chesterfield counties to Williamsburg and the Northern Neck.\n\n2nd District Democrats\n\nIn the Virginia Beach-anchored 2nd District Navy veteran and nonprofit executive Missy Cotter Smasal defeated attorney Jake Denton winning 17,239 votes, or 70% for the Democratic Party nomination to challenge Rep. Jen Kiggans, R-2nd, who is seeking a second term.\n\n\"Thank you to all the voters, volunteers, and donors who have put their faith in me. I'll always have your back,\" Smasal said in a social media post.\n\nRedistricting in 2021 left this district, which includes the Eastern Shore, Suffolk and rural western Tidewater communities in Isle of Wight and Southampton counties more Republican, though national Democrats have targeted Kiggans seeing a possible pick up here.\n\n7th District\n\nIn Northern Virginia's 7th District, an open seat after Democrat Abigail Spanberger decided not to seek another term in order to run for governor next year, Eugene Vindman captured the Democratic nomination. He bested six other Democrats, with 16,170 votes of 49% with 99% of precincts reporting unofficial results.\n\nDerrick Anderson a former U.S. Army Green Beret who lost a GOP primary for a Prince William County board seat in 2022, won the GOP nomination. He prevailed in a six-way GOP race with 15,870 votes, or 46% of votes cast.\n\nVindman, who with his twin brother Alexander played a role in Trump's first impeachment, defeated a state legislator, Del. Briana Sewell, D-Prince William and former Del. Elizabeth Guzman, D-Prince William as well as Prince Willian supervisors Margaret Angela Franklin and Andrea O. Bailey.\n\n\"The stakes of this election couldn't be higher, the passion behind my campaign comes from voters wanting integrity, moderation, and professionalism in a government that works for them; and our grass-roots movement is coming for the extreme MAGA agenda,\" Vindman said in a statement.\n\nThe district is based in Prince William, Stafford and Spotsylvania counties.\n\n10th District\n\nIn Northern Virginia's 10th District, 12 Democrats and four Republicans sought their parties' nominations for the seat of Rep. Jennifer Wexton, D-10th, who is retiring for health reasons.\n\nState Sen. Suhas Subramanyam, D-Loudon, won with 12,859, or 30% of votes cast, with 96% of precincts reporting unofficial results.\n\nSubramanyam, who won Wexton's endorsement, defeated several other current and former Democratic legislators, including state Sen. Jennifer Boysko, D-Fairfax, Del. Dan Helmer, D-Fairfax, Del. David Reid, D-Loudoun, Del, Michelle Lopes Maldonado, D-Prince William, and former Speaker of the House Eileen Filler-Corn, D-Prince William.\n\nSubramanyam said in a statement: \"This district is my home. I got married here. My kids were born here. The issues our community faces are personal to our family.\" He added: This district will remain blue.\"\n\nRepublican Mike Clancy, a lawyer and conservative commentator, won the Republican nomination with 64% of votes cast.\n\nThe district is based in Loudoun and Prince William counties.\n\n11th District\n\nIn Fairfax County's 11th Congressional district, longtime Rep Gerry Connolly fended off a challenge from attorney Ahsan Nasar in the Democratic primary. Connolly had 34,922 votes, or 86% of votes cast, to 5,757 or 14% for Nasar, with 94% of precincts reporting.\n\nPHOTOS: Trump rally in Richmond\n\nDave Ress (804) 649-6948\n\ndress@timesdispatch.com\n\nTimes-Dispatch reporter Michael Martz and Jason Armesto of the Daily Progress contributed to this report.\n\nDave Ress\n\nGrowth and Development Reporter\n\nAuthor twitter Author email Follow Dave Ress Close Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily! Bob Good, who chairs the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, trailed primary challenger state Sen. John McGuire by 327 votes as of 12 a.m. Wednesday morning, according to unofficial returns in the GOP nomination race in the reliably red southern Virginia district.\n\nVirginia observes the Juneteenth holiday, and a resumption of the vote tabulation for the remaining uncounted ballots in the race may not take place until Thursday. The current margin in the election is less than one percent and if it remains under that level, the race would qualify for a recount according to Virginia law.\n\nFOX NEWS POLL: BIDEN, TRUMP IN A DEAD HEAT IN VIRGINIA\n\nGood, who is running for a third term in Congress, aims to avert becoming the first House incumbent this election cycle to be ousted by a primary challenger, in a contentious intra-party primary battle that pitted conservatives versus conservatives and Trump against some of his biggest allies in the House of Representatives.\n\n\"We need leaders that know how to put petty differences aside and bring people together for a better future,\" McGuire, a former Navy SEAL, told supporters on Tuesday night. \"And that's what I'm all about.\"\n\nREAD ON THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nHEAD HERE FOR THE LATEST FOX NEWS PRIMARY RESULTS\n\nHis comments came as he prematurely declared victory in a speech at his election party in Lynchburg, Virginia.\n\nGood did not give a speech at his primary night gathering, which was also held in Lynchburg, but in a social media post he noted that \"we're still waiting on the final election results.\"\n\nIn a race where a whopping $14 million was spent - with much of it targeting the incumbent - Good wrote that \"no matter the outcome, you've shown the DC Swamp that you won't back down from standing for what's right. Keep the faith and don't stop fighting now.\"\n\nGood incurred Trump's wrath for being one of just a handful of House Republicans to endorse Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the GOP presidential primaries.\n\nEven though Good avoided criticizing Trump and quickly endorsed the former president after DeSantis ended his White House bid in January, Trump wrote on this Truth Social platform that \"the damage has been done!\"\n\nThe former president last month endorsed McGuire, who also had the backing of Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia, a conservative firebrand and major Trump ally who is a vocal critic of Good who last year broke with the House Freedom Caucus. The group is considered the most far-right organization of lawmakers in the chamber.\n\nMcCarthy also targeted Good, who was one of eight Republicans last autumn who joined with Democrats to vote to oust McCarthy from his leadership position.\n\nGood had the support of Reps. Matt Gaetz and Byron Donalds of Florida, two conservatives who are also strong backers of Trump.\n\nFellow House Freedom Caucus members, Reps. Chip Roy of Texas and Andy Biggs of Arizona, joined Good in Virginia for a rally on Friday.\n\nEven though he was targeted by Trump, Good spotlighted his support for the former president as he ran for re-election.\n\n\"Happy Birthday to the best and next president of the United States, President Trump!\" Good wrote on social media on Friday, which was the former president's 78th birthday.\n\nGood Good then threw his support behind Trump after DeSantis dropped out.\n\nTrump, while acknowledging Good's \"warm\" endorsement, posted to his social media platform Truth Social on Monday, saying in part, \"Bob Good is BAD FOR VIRGINIA, AND BAD FOR THE USA! He turned his back on our incredible Movement, and was constantly attacking and fighting me until recently, when he gave a warm and \"loving\" Endorsement - But really, it was too late! The damage had been done.\"\n\nThe former president instead offered his \"complete and total endorsement\" for McGuire, a Virginia state senator and former Navy SEAL who backed the pro-Trump \"Stop the Steal\" movement following President Joe Biden's 2020 election win.\n\nWhat We Know\n\nAs of 11:27 p.m. Eastern time, McGuire was leading Good by less than 400 votes with 93 percent counted, according to the Associated Press. The lead had switched hands on more than one occasion earlier in the night.\n\nGood issued a statement on the race just before 11 p.m., thanking his supporters for showing \"the DC Swamp that you won't back down from standing for what's right\" regardless of \"the outcome.\"\n\n\"Right now, we're still waiting on the final election results of today's Primary,\" Good said in the statement, which was shared to X, formerly Twitter. \"The entire DC Swamp was aligned against us with over $10 million in attack ads, but with your help we were able to make this race too close to call.\"\n\nGaetz posted to X on Monday, saying, \"It has been an honor to campaign with my friend and conservative fighter \u2066@GoodForCongress VA5 please get out and vote TODAY for Bob Good!\"\n\nBoebert also shared multiple campaign posts from Good on X in the lead-up to the election. However, the MAGA split was evident as Georgia Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene threw her weight behind McGuire.\n\n\"VA-05 polls close at 7 pm, make sure you vote for the REAL Trump endorsed candidate, John McGuire!!\" Greene posted to X on Tuesday. \"NOT Trump back stabber Bob Good! Also do you want to know the truth about Bob Good and Kevin McCarthy? Sound up! Listen to the end!\"\n\nWhat's Next\n\nThe election outcome remained too close to call at the time of publication. A recount is possible if the candidates are still separated by hundreds of votes or less in the final tally.\n\nRegardless of the final margin, the close finish could indicate that Trump has less sway over Republicans than some might imagine. A poll of 300 likely voters commissioned by the Virginia Faith and Freedom Coalition and conducted earlier this month indicated that McGuire had a solid 10-point lead over Good.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-395204147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:23:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:23:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:21:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.wyff4.com/article/trump-john-mcguire-incumbent-bob-good-virginia/61179528", "title": "The Trump Divide: Sen. John McGuire on track to defeat incumbent Rep. Bob Good in Virginia", "body": "Ballot counting stopped at midnight on Wednesday before a final winner of the Republican primary could be announced for the 5th Congressional District of Virginia. The current count shows state Sen. John McGuire in the lead with 327 more votes than incumbent U.S. Rep. Bob Good, a less-than-shocking development if you have been plugged into the candidates' campaigns over the past several months.Video above: Trump holds campaign rally in WisconsinUnlike many other races, Good and McGuire's bids for the primary nomination have focused on their allegiance to former President Donald Trump rather than on differences in policies, values or party loyalty. While McGuire's efforts to convince Virginians that Good, who backed Trump's campaign for the White House in 2020 and 2024, is a \"never Trumper\" at one time seemed like a losing battle, it is now clear that the voters were listening.The backlash against Good from Trump-loyalists is largely due to his original endorsement of Ron DeSantis for president before the Florida governor dropped out of the Republican primary. While the incumbent switched back to the former president afterward, his decision to support another candidate has led many voters and politicians to call him a backstabber.McGuire faced his own challenges during his campaign, having been elected to a four-year term in Virginia's state senate just one week before he announced his bid for Congress. Good pushed that McGuire was a serial campaigner, telling the Associated Press, \"He's literally a perpetual candidate in search of a race,\" having run for five different positions since 2020. While his argument struck a chord for some, many voters were unconvinced.In February 2024, Good was kicked out of a Trump-themed store in Farmville, where McGuire was permitted to host a meet and greet. The store owner, Karen Angulo, told Good he was not invited and said he was not a \"genuine Trump supporter,\" according to The Daily Progress. Despite Good having voted in line with Trump at a rate of 100% during his presidency, according to FiveThirtyEight, McGuire was able to capitalize off the attention, writing in a statement: \"If you're sick of Bob Good trying to intimidate constituents and stab President Trump and the MAGA movement in the back, vote McGuire.\"On the other side of the aisle, Gloria Tinsley Witt won the Democratic nomination in the 5th District, defeating opponents Gary Terry and Paul Riley. After the results were in, Witt said in a statement to WDBJ, \"I want to extend my heartfelt thanks to the other candidates who ran in this primary. Their passion and commitment to our shared values have strengthened our movement and reminded us all of the importance of unity in our fight for progress. Thank you for your contributions to this race and for your dedication to our community.\"While the Republican primary race has been fraught with name-calling and arguments about who is more loyal to Trump than the other, a recent forum for Democratic candidates showcased an emphasis on the \"unity\" that Witt mentions. At the May event, the District 5 Democratic hopefuls focused on the weak points, infighting and values of the opposing party's candidates rather than their own direct competition. It was less of a discussion about why the Virginian Democratic voter should vote for one candidate or the other and more about why all Virginians need to go out and vote against the Republican primary winner. The candidates did not only agree on policies, they also agreed on who is the real competition.\"Bob Good has got to go,\" Terry said. \"Plain and simple.\"While Good, as the leader of the House Freedom Caucus, seemed most likely to take the spot as frontrunner in the battle for the GOP nomination, Trump's endorsement of his opponent might be the final nail in the coffin for a fight that hinged on loyalty to the former president.Despite Good's praise for Trump and his history of voting in line with the ex-president while he was still in office, his support still appears lacking to many Republican voters. And because this race has little to do with policies -- McGuire's website does not even list any policies, but it does have a picture of Trump's social media post deriding Good on its homepage -- even just a small dose of disloyalty might dislodge Good from the House of Representatives as the first incumbent to lose in a primary this year.While many Republicans are relying on their support of Trump to secure votes, the election results in Virginia's 5th District primary may beg the question: How much do you need to prove your loyalty to Trump to maintain power as the traditional Republican Party is overthrown?McGuire ended his Tuesday night victory speech by saying, \"Let's win this thing ... let's get Trump over the finish line and let's save America and make America great again,\" concluding with the former president's campaign slogan, a new tradition for 21st-century GOP candidates.\n\nBallot counting stopped at midnight on Wednesday before a final winner of the Republican primary could be announced for the 5Congressional District of Virginia. The current count shows state Sen. John McGuire in the lead with 327 more votes than incumbent U.S. Rep. Bob Good, a less-than-shocking development if you have been plugged into the candidates' campaigns over the past several months.\n\nVideo above: Trump holds campaign rally in Wisconsin\n\nUnlike many other races, Good and McGuire's bids for the primary nomination have focused on their allegiance to former President Donald Trump rather than on differences in policies, values or party loyalty. While McGuire's efforts to convince Virginians that Good, who backed Trump's campaign for the White House in 2020 and 2024, is a \"never Trumper\" at one time seemed like a losing battle, it is now clear that the voters were listening.\n\nThe backlash against Good from Trump-loyalists is largely due to his original endorsement of Ron DeSantis for president before the Florida governor dropped out of the Republican primary. While the incumbent switched back to the former president afterward, his decision to support another candidate has led many voters and politicians to call him a backstabber.\n\nMcGuire faced his own challenges during his campaign, having been elected to a four-year term in Virginia's state senate just one week before he announced his bid for Congress. Good pushed that McGuire was a serial campaigner, telling the Associated Press, \"He's literally a perpetual candidate in search of a race,\" having run for five different positions since 2020. While his argument struck a chord for some, many voters were unconvinced.\n\nIn February 2024, Good was kicked out of a Trump-themed store in Farmville, where McGuire was permitted to host a meet and greet. The store owner, Karen Angulo, told Good he was not invited and said he was not a \"genuine Trump supporter,\" according to The Daily Progress. Despite Good having voted in line with Trump at a rate of 100% during his presidency, according to FiveThirtyEight, McGuire was able to capitalize off the attention, writing in a statement: \"If you're sick of Bob Good trying to intimidate constituents and stab President Trump and the MAGA movement in the back, vote McGuire.\"\n\nOn the other side of the aisle, Gloria Tinsley Witt won the Democratic nomination in the 5 District, defeating opponents Gary Terry and Paul Riley. After the results were in, Witt said in a statement to WDBJ, \"I want to extend my heartfelt thanks to the other candidates who ran in this primary. Their passion and commitment to our shared values have strengthened our movement and reminded us all of the importance of unity in our fight for progress. Thank you for your contributions to this race and for your dedication to our community.\"\n\nWhile the Republican primary race has been fraught with name-calling and arguments about who is more loyal to Trump than the other, a recent forum for Democratic candidates showcased an emphasis on the \"unity\" that Witt mentions.\n\nAt the May event, the District 5 Democratic hopefuls focused on the weak points, infighting and values of the opposing party's candidates rather than their own direct competition. It was less of a discussion about why the Virginian Democratic voter should vote for one candidate or the other and more about why all Virginians need to go out and vote against the Republican primary winner. The candidates did not only agree on policies, they also agreed on who is the real competition.\n\n\"Bob Good has got to go,\" Terry said. \"Plain and simple.\"\n\nWhile Good, as the leader of the House Freedom Caucus, seemed most likely to take the spot as frontrunner in the battle for the GOP nomination, Trump's endorsement of his opponent might be the final nail in the coffin for a fight that hinged on loyalty to the former president.\n\nDespite Good's praise for Trump and his history of voting in line with the ex-president while he was still in office, his support still appears lacking to many Republican voters. And because this race has little to do with policies -- McGuire's website does not even list any policies, but it does have a picture of Trump's social media post deriding Good on its homepage -- even just a small dose of disloyalty might dislodge Good from the House of Representatives as the first incumbent to lose in a primary this year.\n\nWhile many Republicans are relying on their support of Trump to secure votes, the election results in Virginia's 5 District primary may beg the question: How much do you need to prove your loyalty to Trump to maintain power as the traditional Republican Party is overthrown?\n\nMcGuire ended his Tuesday night victory speech by saying, \"Let's win this thing ... let's get Trump over the finish line and let's save America and make America great again,\" {"uri": "8187790018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "22:39:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T22:39:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T22:38:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jun/20/bob-good-virginia-republican-primary-trump", "title": "Tense wait in tight Virginia primary for House Republican who crossed Trump", "body": "Incumbent Bob Good, chair of far-right Freedom Caucus, appeals for patience as votes counted in congressional race\n\nThe conservative US representative Bob Good is asking for \"patience from the people of Virginia's fifth district over the coming weeks\" as he hopes the final ballot count from Tuesday's primary will allow him to fend off a fellow Republican challenger endorsed by former president Donald Trump.\n\nGood, who chairs the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, currently trails state senator John McGuire by a little over 300 votes as elections officials finalize their vote counts and mail-in ballots continue to trickle in.\n\nMcGuire claimed victory late on Tuesday, but the Associated Press has not called the race for either candidate.\n\nMcGuire's lead has so far remained relatively stable, shrinking slightly to 313 votes on Thursday afternoon from 327 votes at midnight on Wednesday.\n\nIn an email, Good's campaign manager, Diana Shores, noted that mail-in ballots arriving at local election offices by noon on Friday still must be counted. Provisional ballots are also still being counted.\n\n\"There is no way anyone can know for certain how many mail-in ballots are pending for count,\" she said.\n\nIf Good loses, he would be the first House incumbent to lose a primary challenge this year, with the exception of one race in which two incumbents faced off due to redistricting.\n\nAs one of the most conservative congressmen in the country, Good might be impervious to a primary challenge under normal circumstances. But he earned Trump's wrath when he endorsed the Florida governor, Ron DeSantis, for president. He switched back to Trump after DeSantis dropped out, but Trump endorsed McGuire and called Good a backstabber.\n\nMcGuire's lead translates to a margin of about half a percentage point out of more than 62,000 ballots cast. Once the results are certified, Virginia law allows for a recount if the margin of victory is less than a percentage point. If it is within half a percentage point, the recount can be conducted at the state's expense.\n\nIn a social media post on Wednesday, Good said the race remained too close to call.\n\n\"We are asking for full transparency from the officials involved,\" he said.\n\nBoth Good and McGuire are among Republicans who have raised concerns about election integrity in the wake of Trump's false claims of voter fraud in his 2020 re-election defeat. Good was among more than 100 GOP House members who voted in January 2021 to object to the electoral college count from states that Trump disputed.\n\nIn a pre-election telephone rally with Trump on Monday, McGuire urged supporters to deliver him a margin of victory \"too big to rig\".", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [], "concepts": This race, significant for its impact on the heavily Republican district in Virginia, reflects broader GOP tensions and power struggles, especially after Good's controversial decisions against former President Trump and moderate Republicans.\n\nU.S. Representative Bob Good, the leader of a bloc of hardline House Republicans, faces off on Tuesday against a primary challenger backed by both Donald Trump and a key group of moderate Republicans. The winner of the contest between the House Freedom Caucus chair and former Navy SEAL John McGuire is expected to easily carry the strongly Republican-leaning southern Virginia district in the Nov. 5 election, when control of the White House and both chambers of Congress will be up for grabs.\n\nGood angered former President Trump by endorsing Florida Governor Ron DeSantis in his Republican presidential primary campaign against Trump, switching his endorsement to Trump only after DeSantis dropped out. Good also ignited the ire of moderate Republicans after he voted to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his role in October, launching weeks of chaos and bitter, highly public infighting as Republicans attempted to coalesce around a replacement.\n\nTrump endorsed Good's challenger McGuire, a Virginia state senator, in a May social media post. Defending Main Street, the super PAC affiliated with the moderate Republican Main Street Caucus, has spent $600,000 on ads to defeat Good. \"He's a Republican in name only,\" Sarah Chamberlain, CEO of the Republican Main Street Partnership, the nonprofit organization affiliated with the caucus, said. The group does not normally work to oust incumbents, she said, calling Good \"a unique situation\" after he campaigned against moderate Republican colleagues and voted against Republican bills on the House floor.\n\nFollowing Trump's endorsement of McGuire, Good said in a statement, \"I have never been the choice of political power brokers in Washington.\" DEMOCRATS NOMINATE CANDIDATES\n\nVirginia Democrats and Republicans will also pick candidates on Tuesday to vie for the seats currently held by Democratic U.S. Representatives Jennifer Wexton and Abigail Spanberger, both elected in 2018 when their party won control of the House for the second half of Trump's term. The districts could also play an important role in Democrats' efforts to win back a House majority in November.\n\nIn Virginia's 7th district, Eugene Vindman, the brother of Alexander Vindman, who played an important role in Trump's first impeachment, was projected by the Associated Press to win the Democratic nomination for Spanberger's seat, which she is leaving to run for governor. Derrick Anderson, a former Green Beret, and Cameron Hamilton, a former NAVY Seal, are jostling for the Republican nomination in the competitive district where many military families live.\n\nIn Virginia's 10th district, Democratic candidates seeking to succeed the retiring Wexton include state Representative Dan Helmer, state Senator Suhas Subramanyam and Eileen Filler-Corn, former speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates. The winner of Tuesday's primary is strongly favored to win the heavily Democratic district in November. Polls closed in Virginia at 7 p.m. (2300 GMT).\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "8184576031", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:23:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:23:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:22:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/race-between-key-us-house-republican-and-trump-backed-challenger-too-close-to-call/article_598731da-a05c-535b-847d-f63c0e53652b.html", "title": "Race between key US House Republican and Trump-backed challenger too close to call", "body": "By Moira Warburton\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -The race between U.S. Representative Bob Good, a prominent hardline House Republican, and a primary challenger backed by both Donald Trump and a key group of moderate Republicans, remained too close to call on Tuesday night.\n\nThe winner of the contest between Good, chair of the House Freedom Caucus, and former Navy SEAL John McGuire is expected to easily carry the strongly Republican-leaning southern Virginia district in the Nov. 5 election, when control of the White House and both chambers of Congress will be up for grabs.\n\nVirginia state laws allow for a recount if results are within one percentage point. McGuire led Good by 0.4% - less than 300 votes - with 92% of votes counted, according to the Associated Press at time of publication.\n\nGood angered former President Trump by endorsing Florida Governor Ron DeSantis in his Republican presidential primary campaign against Trump, switching his endorsement to Trump only after DeSantis dropped out.\n\nGood also ignited the ire of moderate Republicans after he voted to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his role in October, launching weeks of chaos and bitter, highly public infighting as Republicans attempted to coalesce around a replacement.\n\nTrump endorsed Good's challenger McGuire, a Virginia state senator, in a May social media post. Defending Main Street, the super PAC affiliated with the moderate Republican Main Street Caucus, has spent $600,000 on ads to defeat Good.\n\n\"He's a Republican in name only,\" Sarah Chamberlain, CEO of the Republican Main Street Partnership, the nonprofit organization affiliated with the caucus, said. The group does not normally work to oust incumbents, she said, calling Good \"a unique situation\" after he campaigned against moderate Republican colleagues and voted against Republican bills on the House floor.\n\nFollowing Trump's endorsement of McGuire, Good said in a statement, \"I have never been the choice of political power brokers in Washington.\"\n\nDEMOCRATS NOMINATE CANDIDATES\n\nVirginia Democrats and Republicans will also pick candidates on Tuesday to vie for the seats currently held by Democratic U.S. Representatives Jennifer Wexton and Abigail Spanberger, both elected in 2018 when their party won control of the House for the second half of Trump's term.\n\nThe districts could also play an important role in Democrats' efforts to win back a House majority in November.\n\nIn Virginia's 7th district, Eugene Vindman, the brother of Alexander Vindman, who played an important role in Trump's first impeachment, was projected by the Associated Press to win the Democratic nomination for Spanberger's seat, which she is leaving to run for governor.\n\nDerrick Anderson, a former Green Beret, beat Cameron Hamilton, a former NAVY Seal, for the Republican nomination in the competitive district where many military families live, according to the Associated Press.\n\nIn Virginia's 10th district, state Senator Democratic Suhas Subramanyam edged out a win in a crowded race to succeed the retiring Wexton, who endorsed him in May. The winner of Tuesday's primary is strongly favored to win the heavily Democratic district in November.\n\nPolls closed in Virginia at 7 p.m. (2300 GMT).\n\n(Reporting by Moira Warburton in Bob Good vs. Trump-backed challenger election still too close to call", "body": "With more than 95% of the results for Virginia's primary election on Tuesday, the outcome of the hotly contested primary race between Republican incumbent Representative Bob Good and state Senator John McGuire was still too close to call.\n\nAs of Thursday morning, McGuire led Good by just 324 votes, or just .52%, out of 62,536 votes cast in the Republican primary race for Virginia's fifth congressional district.\n\nGood, a conservative Republican who chairs the House Freedom Caucus, has represented Virginia's fifth district since 2020 and is seeking a third term.\n\nMcGuire is a Virginia state senator representing the 56th district, which encompasses the north and west of Richmond. Before becoming a state Senator in 2023, he served on Virginia's House of Delegates.\n\nDespite a still-undecided election, McGuire's posts on X, formerly known as Twitter, on Wednesday suggested he expects victory.\n\n\"Thank you to my family, thank you to everyone who helped out on this campaign, thank you to the people who endorsed and supported me, and thank you to Donald J. Trump for believing in me. There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory,\" he wrote. \"\n\nFor his part, Good said that they are still waiting on the results of mail-in and provisional ballots.\n\n\"Right now, we're still waiting on the final election results of today's Primary,\" he posted on social media. \"The entire DC Swamp was aligned against us with over $10 million in attack ads, but with your help, we were able to make this race too close to call.\"\n\nVirginia's 5th Congressional District is a Republican stronghold that voted for former President Donald Trump in 2016 and 2020. It would seem a safe place for a conservative congressman like Good to be re-elected.\n\nBut Good earned Trump's wrath after initially endorsing Florida Governor Ron DeSantis for president. After DeSantis dropped out, he switched to supporting Trump, but the former president endorsed Good's opponent instead.\n\n\"Bob Good is BAD FOR VIRGINIA, AND BAD FOR THE USA. He turned his back on our incredible movement, and was constantly attacking and fighting me until recently, when he gave a warm and 'loving' Endorsement,\" Trump said in a Truth Social post. \"John McGuire has my Complete and Total Endorsement!\"\n\nLater, Trump's attorneys sent Good a cease-and-desist letter for using the presumptive Republican nominee's name and likeness on campaign materials.\n\nOnce the votes are finally tallied, Virginia law allows for a recount if the margin of victory is less than a percentage point. If the ballot count is within half a percentage point, the recount can be conducted at the state's expense, according to the Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", Good Locked in Tight Race With Trump-Backed Challenger", "body": "LYNCHBURG, Va. -- Rep. Bob Good (R-Va.) is locked in a tight race with Trump-backed Virginia state Sen. John McGuire.\n\nThe race may not be called on June 18 if the results remain close and it may ultimately head to a recount. A candidate may request a recount if the difference between candidates is 1 percent or less, according to Virginia law.\n\nMr. Good, chair of the staunchly conservative House Freedom Caucus, risks being the first House incumbent to go down to a primary challenge this year, with the exception of one race in which two incumbents faced off due to redistricting.\n\nThe incumbent, in a late-night post on X urged supporters to \"[k]eep the faith and don't stop fighting now.\"\n\n\"The entire DC Swamp was aligned against us with over $10 million in attack ads, but with your help we were able to make this race too close to call,\" Mr. Good wrote\n\nDespite the race not being called, Mr. Guire, a former Navy SEAL, declared victory at his watch party in Lynchburg at about 11:30 p.m.\n\nThe contentious primary battle has been largely defined by loyalty to former President Trump. Mr. Good had initially endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the presidential race, before flipping to the former president after the governor dropped out.\n\nFormer President Trump and Mr. McGuire have cast Mr. Good as disloyal to the presumptive Republican nominee. Former President Trump, in a Truth Social post, said that despite the House Freedom Caucus chair's subsequent endorsement, \"the damage had been done.\"\n\nWhen previously asked if he regretted endorsing Mr. DeSantis, Mr. Good said \"The time for talking about previous endorsements is over.\"\n\nHe said, following a June 7 rally on the lawn in front of a courthouse in Powhatan, Virginia, that it's time to unite behind former President Trump.\n\nIn interviews with The Epoch Times outside polling places on June 18, voters explained why they voted for either Mr. McGuire or Mr. Good.\n\nJimmy, who was wearing a Make America Great Again hat and a shirt with faces of former President Trump plastered all over, said he supported Mr. McGuire simply because \"Trump endorsed him\" even though Mr. Good \"did an alright job.\"\n\nJames said he pulled the lever for Mr. McGuire even though he did not like either candidate but in the end had to pick one. He said there needs to be a change in the U.S. government. He also cited former President Trump's endorsement of Mr. McGuire.\n\nHowever, Ray said he cast his ballot for Mr. McGuire because \"he's the better choice\" and given his experience as a Navy SEAL.\n\nDavid, on the other hand, voted for Mr. Good, he said, simply \"because he's a conservative.\"\n\nKay said she cast her ballot for Mr. Good because \"of his record,\" though she did not specify which policies she appreciates.\n\nAll interviewees declined to provide their last names.\n\nWhile Mr. Good received endorsements from a dozen or so members of the House Freedom Caucus, Mr. McGuire boasted backing from some prominent Republicans, including Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) and House Armed Services Committee Chairman Mike Rogers (R-Ala.).\n\nOne Freedom Caucus member, Rep. Warren Davidson (R-Ohio), supported Mr. McGuire, calling him \"conservative and effective.\"\n\nMr. Good was one of eight Republicans to join all Democrats in ousting former Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) as House Speaker in October.\n\nA super PAC affiliated with Republican Main Street Partnership, a group that supports moderate Republicans, has spent more than $450,000 to defeat the GOP incumbent, according to Open Secrets.\n\nThe seat is likely to stay in GOP hands as Mr. Good won reelection in 2022 with 57.6 percent of the vote.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", Bob Good, who chairs the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, trailed primary challenger state Sen. John McGuire by less than 350 votes as of 12 a.m. Wednesday morning in the GOP nomination race in the reliably red southern Virginia district.\n\nVirginia observes the Juneteenth holiday, and a resumption of the vote tabulation for the remaining uncounted ballots in the race may not take place until Thursday.\n\nFOX NEWS POLL: BIDEN, TRUMP IN A DEAD HEAT IN VIRGINIA\n\nGood, who is running for a third term in Congress, aims to avert becoming the first House incumbent this election cycle to be ousted by a primary challenger, in a contentious intra-party primary battle that pitted conservatives versus conservatives and Trump against some of his biggest allies in the House of Representatives.\n\n\"We need leaders that know how to put petty differences aside and bring people together for a better future,\" McGuire, a former Navy SEAL, told supporters on Tuesday night. \"And that's what I'm all about.\"\n\nHEAD HERE FOR THE LATEST FOX NEWS PRIMARY RESULTS\n\nHis comments came as he prematurely declared victory in a speech at his election party in Lynchburg, Virginia.\n\nGood did not give a speech at his primary night gathering, which was also held in Lynchburg, but in a social media post he noted that \"we're still waiting on the final election results.\"\n\nIn a race where a whopping $14 million was spent - with much of it targeting the incumbent - Good wrote that \"no matter the outcome, you've shown the DC Swamp that you won't back down from standing for what's right. Keep the faith and don't stop fighting now.\"\n\nGood incurred Trump's wrath for being one of just a handful of House Republicans to endorse Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the GOP presidential primaries.\n\nEven though Good avoided criticizing Trump and quickly endorsed the former president after DeSantis ended his White House bid in January, Trump wrote on this Truth Social platform that \"the damage has been done!\"\n\nThe former president last month endorsed McGuire, who also had the backing of Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia, a conservative firebrand and major Trump ally who is a vocal critic of Good who last year broke with the House Freedom Caucus. The group is considered the most far-right organization of lawmakers in the chamber.\n\nMcCarthy also targeted Good, who was one of eight Republicans last autumn who joined with Democrats to vote to oust McCarthy from his leadership position.\n\nGood had the support of Reps. Matt Gaetz and Byron Donalds of Florida, two conservatives who are also strong backers of Trump.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nFellow House Freedom Caucus members, Reps. Chip Roy of Texas and Andy Biggs of Arizona, joined Good in Virginia for a rally on Friday.\n\nEven though he was targeted by Trump, Good spotlighted his support for the former president as he ran for re-election.\n\n\"Happy Birthday to the best and next president of the United States, President Trump!\" Good wrote on social media on Friday, which was the former president's 78th birthday.\n\nGood Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nA Virginia primary congressional race between a right-wing firebrand incumbent and a challenger endorsed by Donald Trump remained too close to call on Wednesday morning -- but that didn't stop the former president's candidate of choice from prematurely declaring victory.\n\nJohn McGuire, a Virginia state senator, was endorsed by Trump after Representative Bob Good, a two-term incumbent who serves as chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, came out in support of Florida Governor Ron DeSantis for the Republican nomination for president. As of Wednesday morning, only 315 votes stood between Good and McGuire in Virginia's 5th congressional district.\n\nNonetheless, McGuire declared victory Tuesday evening.\n\n\"Thank you to my family, thank you to everyone who helped out on this campaign, thank you to the people who endorsed and supported me, and thank you to Donald J. Trump for believing in me,\" McGuire posted on X, formerly known as Twitter. \"There are still a few votes left to count, but it's clear that all paths end with a victory.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Good applauded his campaign for the close race despite a lack of support from Trump and the Republican establishment.\n\n\"The entire DC Swamp was aligned against us with over $10 million in attack ads, but with your help we were able to make this race too close to call,\" he said. \"No matter the outcome, you've shown the DC Swamp that you won't back down from standing for what's right. Keep the faith and don't stop fighting now.\"\n\nGood has become an outspoken right-wing figure since he joined the House of Representatives in 2021. He vocally opposed Kevin McCarthy's bid to become speaker of the House in January of last year. When Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida filed his motion to remove McCarthy, Good joined Democrats and seven Republicans in supporting it.\n\nDuring the fight to replace replace McCarthy, Good was one of a handful of hardliners who opposed electing House Majority Leader Steve Scalise as speaker. He later threw his weight behind Mike Johnson, as did the rest of the House Republican conference.\n\nMcCarthy and a prominent political action committee ultimately poured money into an effort to oppose Good's bid. Trump endorsed McGuire despite the fact that Good traveled to New York in May to support the former president in his hush money trial. McGuire also made the trip.\n\n\"John is running against Bob Good, who is not good. Despite his name, he's very bad for Virginia,\" Trump told supporters on Monday.\n\nGood enjoyed the support of Gaetz, as well as former Trump chief of staff Mark Meadows and Representative Chip Roy of Texas. Meanwhile, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, who has been kicked out of the Freedom Caucus, backed McGuire.\n\nVirginia's 5th district, which includes Charlottesville and the University of Virginia as well as nearby suburbs and rural areas. has seen frequent turnover. Indeed, Good defeated incumbent Republican Denver Riggleman in 2020 largely in response to Riggleman presiding over a same-sex wedding.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8185169382", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:03:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:03:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:02:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailysignal.com/2024/06/19/virginia-gop-primary-race-between-trump-endorsee-and-house-conservative-too-close-to-call/", "title": "Virginia GOP Primary Race Between Trump Endorsee and House Conservative Too Close to Call", "body": "It's still to close to call the winner in a Republican primary contest in Virginia that garnered national attention, featuring a challenger endorsed by former President Donald Trump running against an incumbent congressman and chairman of the House Freedom Caucus\n\nAt 11 p.m. Tuesday, McGuire held a lead of 50.3% of the vote to Good's 49.7%, with 96% of the votes counted, according to NBC News.\n\nGood ran for his third term representing Virginia's 5th Congressional District, which spans Charlottesville, the suburbs of Richmond, and through Lynchburg and Danville close to the border with North Carolina. The Freedom Caucus, which Good leads, represents House conservatives.\n\nTrump opposed Good, who had endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in the Republican presidential primary March 5. In that contest, Trump easily defeated his former U.N. ambassador, Nikki Haley, as well as DeSantis, who had dropped out.\n\nIn a June 17 post on Truth Social, his social media platform, Trump wrote: \"Bob Good is BAD FOR VIRGINIA, AND BAD FOR THE USA! He turned his back on our incredible Movement, and was constantly attacking and fighting me until recently, when he gave a warm and 'loving' Endorsement - But really, it was too late!\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., whom Good voted last year to oust, also endorsed McGuire. So did the centrist Republican Mainstreet Partnership.\n\nGood had the endorsements of former Trump adviser and \"War Room\" host Steve Bannon, as well as the backing of former U.S. Rep. Dave Brat, a former Freedom Caucus member best known for ousting one-time House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in a GOP primary.\n\nIn the November general election, whichever candidate wins will face Democrat candidate Gloria Tinsley Witt, a businesswoman and activist. She defeated Gary Terry and Paul Riley. The Associated Press called the race at 8:19 p.m.\n\nMcGuire, a former Navy SEAL, has been criticized for being in the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, when rioters clashed with Capitol Police as a joint session of Congress met to certify Joe Biden's Electoral College victory over Trump in the 2020 election.\n\nMcGuire called Good a \"never Trumper\" during the campaign.\n\nGood has said he considered Trump the best president in his lifetime, but endorsed DeSantis because Trump is constitutionally limited to only one more four-year term, The Associated Press reported.\n\nAlso on the Virginia front, the primary results will determine who vies for open seats in the U.S. House of Representatives created by the pending retirements of two incumbent Democrats.\n\nIn 2018, Rep. Abigail Spanberger won the once Republican-leaning 7th Congressional District, defeating Brat, the incumbent Republican. Spanberger reportedly plans to run for Virginia governor in 2025.\n\nThe congressional district spans northern and central Virginia.\n\nRetired Army Col. Eugene Vindman won the Democratic primary to fill the seat being vacated by Spanberger. He is the twin brother of retired Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, who became famous for his congressional testimony during the first Trump impeachment in 2019. The AP called the race at 8:06 p.m.\n\nVindman had the endorsement of Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., who was censured by the House and removed from the House Intelligence Committee he once chaired for making repeated misleading statements to the public.\n\nIn the primary, Vindman took on current and former elected officials, including state Delegate Briana Sewell, Prince William County Board of Supervisors member Andrea Bailey, and former state Delegate Elizabeth Guzman.\n\nOn the Republican side former Green Beret Derrick Anderson defeated former Navy SEAL Cameron Hamilton. The AP called the race at 9 p.m.\n\nAlso, Rep. Jennifer Wexton, a Democrat, isn't seeking another term representing the 10th Congressional District in Northern Virginia, just outside Washington, D.C.\n\nThe Wexton-endorsed Virginia state Sen. Suhas Subramanyam won a 12-candidate primary among Democrats.\n\nOther contenders included former Virginia House Speaker Eileen Filler-Corn, state Sen. Dan Helmer, Jennifer Boysko, and former Virginia Education Secretary Atif Qarni. The AP called the race at 9:15 p.m.\n\nLawyer Mike Clancy won the Republican primary in the congressional district, which leans heavily Democrat, defeating Aliscia Andrews, who ran for the seat in 2020. {"uri": "8184588341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:37:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:37:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:36:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/cliffhanger-congressional-contest-between-bob-good-and-john-mcguire-tests-power-of-trump-endorsement/article_4b45e55c-51e8-567c-9c17-cda0cbdbc2e4.html", "title": "Cliffhanger congressional contest between Bob Good and John McGuire tests power of Trump endorsement", "body": "Democratic congressional candidate Briana Sewell poses for a picture, Wednesday, May 29, 2024, in Woodbridge, Va.\n\nBy MATTHEW BARAKAT and BEN FINLEY - Associated Press\n\nFALLS CHURCH, Va. (AP) -- One of America's most conservative congressmen was locked in a tight renomination battle against an opponent endorsed by former President Donald Trump in Virginia's primary election Tuesday.\n\nRep. Bob Good, who chairs the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, is seeking a third term representing Virginia's 5th Congressional District, but state Sen. John McGuire has mounted a strong challenge that highlights frictions in the party.\n\nThe close margin made the race too early to call.\n\nMeanwhile, in House District 10, voters chose Suhas Subramanyam from a field of 12 Democrats to try to hold the seat held by U.S. Rep. Jennifer Wexton, who is not seeking reelection to her northern Virginia seat after being diagnosed with a rare, incurable neurological illness.\n\nPeople are also reading... PBS Appalachia studio to open late fall inside Hard Rock Corner Dog House keeps the tradition going EMORY & HENRY ATHLETICS: Sensabaugh has personal investment in new role as E&H AD PREP FOOTBALL NOTES: Virginia High vs. John Marshall to occur on gridiron; Richlands has new O.C. in Bubba Edwards; Honaker coach faces legal issues Burger Bar moves customers to a different era Board approves exception for Taylors Valley cafe Isaiah 117 House breaks ground for new home in Bristol, Va. Local Briefs: Laisure transfers to Science Hill; Honaker's Lowe earns all-state soccer honors Man arrested after driving vehicle with deceased female in rear seat Blueberries abound at the Berry Patch Farm TBI investigating fatal officer-involved shooting Local Briefs: Eastside's Clay earns Class 1 softball player of the year award Bristol Casino reports second highest revenue month since opening Forbes Hubbard stepping down from city school board Charges filed following pursuit, head-on collision in Wise County\n\nIn House District 7, voters chose Eugene Vindman in a crowded Democratic primary to try to hold the seat being vacated by U.S. Rep. Abigail Spanberger, a popular incumbent who is running for governor in 2025.\n\nStatewide, voters selected Hung Cao as the Republican nominee to the U.S. Senate to take on Democrat Tim Kaine.\n\nHere's a look at the major battles on the ballot:\n\nHouse District 5\n\nConventional politics might suggest a congressman with the conservative credentials of Good would be safe in a primary. But he earned the wrath of Trump when he endorsed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis for president. He switched back to Trump after DeSantis dropped out, but Trump is endorsing McGuire and portraying Good as a backstabber.\n\nTrump continued to bash Good as he campaigned for McGuire in a telephone rally Monday night.\n\n\"Unlike Bob Good, John McGuire will not let you down,\" Trump said, adding that McGuire is \"strong on the border\" and \"will always defend your under-siege Second Amendment.\"\n\nGood, for his part, says he considers Trump the best president in his lifetime and only endorsed DeSantis because Trump is constitutionally limited to only one more term.\n\nGood also alienated Republican insiders by voting to oust House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, throwing the party into a measure of chaos.\n\nSeeking to capitalize is McGuire, a state legislator and former Navy SEAL who has echoed Trump's attacks on Good, calling him a \"never Trumper.\"\n\nGood has bashed McGuire as a serial campaigner who announced his congressional bid just one week after winning election to a four-year term in the state Senate.\n\nIf Good loses, he would be the first House incumbent to go down to a primary challenge this year, with the exception of one race in which two incumbents faced off due to redistricting.\n\nThe winner will face Democrat Gloria Tinsley Witt, who defeated Gary Terry and Paul Riley.\n\nThe 5th Congressional District stretches from Charlottesville in the north, past the far western suburbs of Richmond, through Lynchburg and down to Danville and the North Carolina border.\n\nHouse District 7\n\nVindman, a political newcomer who was nonetheless familiar to voters for his role in Trump's first impeachment, has won the Democratic nomination in the 7th Congressional District for what will be a closely watched congressional seat in November.\n\nVindman, who crushed his opponents in fundraising, won in a crowded seven-person field that included four women of color who were all current or former officeholders in Prince William County, a suburban area outside the nation's capital that constitutes the largest portion of the district.\n\nThe former Army officer gained a measure of fame when he and his twin brother, Alex, reported their concerns about Trump's 2019 call to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in which Trump sought an investigation of Biden and his son, Hunter.\n\nVindman highlighted his opposition to Trump in his campaign and in a victory statement issued Tuesday evening said \"our grass-roots movement is coming for the extreme MAGA agenda. Virginia voters are first and foremost values driven, and want to elect leaders with integrity who preserve fundamental rights and freedoms and not extremists.\"\n\nHe faced criticism from some local officials who said he was unconnected to the region's political dynamics.\n\nIn a battle between a former Army Green Beret and a former Navy SEAL, Republican voters chose the Army man, Derrick Anderson, over Navy veteran Cameron Hamilton.\n\nAnderson and Hamilton were the top two fundraisers in a six-person field. Anderson drew support from House GOP leadership in Washington, while Hamilton had support from members of the House Freedom Caucus.\n\nThe district, which stretches from Prince William County south to Fredericksburg and west past Culpeper, tilts just slightly toward Democrats.\n\nHouse District 10\n\nSubramanyam defeated fellow Democratic candidates former Virginia House Speaker Eileen Filler-Corn, state Sens. Dan Helmer and Jennifer Boysko, and former Virginia Education Secretary Atif Qarni. Wexton endorsed Subramanyam.\n\nRepublican voters chose Mike Clancy from a field of four candidates.\n\nHouse District 2\n\nIn Virginia's coastal 2nd Congressional District, Missy Cotter Smasal, a Navy veteran who runs a nonprofit that honors fallen servicewomen, defeated Jeremiah \"Jake\" Denton IV, a constitutional law and civil rights attorney, in the Democratic primary.\n\nShe'll face Republican U.S. Rep. Jen Kiggans in November.\n\nIn a statement Tuesday evening, Smasal took aim at Kiggans and \"the MAGA extremism she supports in Congress.\"\n\n\"I will protect abortion rights and access for all and fight for resources for veterans and military families,\" Smasal said. \"I will always defend democracy and reject party extremism.\"\n\nU.S. Senate\n\nIn the Republican primary for U.S. Senate, Navy veteran Cao prevailed over his four opponents for a chance to try to unseat Kaine, a Democrat who is seeking his third term as the state's junior U.S. senator.\n\nCao had the most money and previous campaign experience running for higher officer among the Republican primary contenders. He also had Trump's endorsement.\n\nIn a victory post on Facebook, Cao immediately criticized President Joe Biden's decision on Tuesday to allow certain U.S. citizens' spouses without legal status to apply eventually for citizenship.\n\n\"Tomorrow, we begin our campaign to save the country that saved my life,\" Cao stated. \"I spent twenty-five years in the Navy, while Tim Kaine spent thirty years in elected office.\"\n\nCao defeated Scott Parkinson, a former congressional staffer for DeSantis, as well as Jonathan Emord, an author and lawyer who often cites his court battles against the Food and Drug Administration. The other Republican candidates were Eddie Garcia, a U.S. Army veteran who owns a mobile app that serves veterans, and Chuck Smith, a former Navy Judge Advocate General's Corps commander and an attorney.\n\nFinley contributed to this report from Norfolk.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press.
